description:
Hunter's Point landmark brewery now. Closest one to the new Shipyard development 

Friday nights pop-up restaurant with Keith. Great local atmosphere. 

Meet your neighbors here. Good tasting brew and friendly staff.
author: Jack C.

description:
Glad to see the Taproom is up and running again. I sincerely hope that they can make it work this time around because they have a great space + the beers are well made

Overall Thoughts

Keep pouring out the great beers!
author: Eddie W.

description:
What a find! Once you step into the door, the ambiance hits you and boy does it feel good. Seriously this is the coolest place to grab a beer or two with the homies. There is a great selection of brews to enjoy. It is nice when there is something for everyone. I really enjoyed the refreshing Hunters Point Pale Ale. Did I mention there are other libations to enjoy, such as classic bottled Coca-Cola? Well there are. Plus, a bag of chips or a pretzel can be snacked on while chillin' and enjoying a refreshment.
It is really cool that events can be hosted here. The events are posted up at the bar. Some events involve food.
author: Danielle G.

description: Great beer selection!!! Cool vibes! Great atmosphere! The bartender Nick was sooooooo amazing though!!! He was so knowledgeable and gave a few samples of his favorite beers so we would really enjoy our experience! Thank you!!
author: Staci H.

description: Great beer & friendly people. They recommended  Brewery's in the area since I told the bartender that I LOVE IPA's!
author: Karmela Z.

description: Brett and Matt the bartenders were AMAZING in helping us pick some beers that would satisfy us. We later met NIck the manager who was also as kind and as hospital. The best part about the amazing brewery for us is they have a DOG FRIENDLY PATIO. Not to mention their amazing beer selection that caters to each individual person. I am planning on returning at least once a month from Big Sur from this awesome experience
author: Sara M.

description:
Awww, I'm sad to see that a quality craft brewery in the form of Speakeasy has bitten the dust, or is about to, as it appears that they haven't closed entirely yet and are looking for a sale. You could easily find their Big Daddy IPA and Prohibition Ale all around town, and at their gorgeous tap room you could find more of their tasty brews.

I personally enjoyed Speakeasy greatly, and they had big, fun community events at their brewery from time to time. I hope Speakeasy's closure isn't a sign that there's too much capacity in the craft brewing industry and that a mass wave of closures is imminent. RIP.
author: Vincent L.

description: One of my favorite beers, great place, very welcoming and great for groups. The staff is very friendly really good IPAS and stouts. My go to beer is the Double Daddy and the Old GodFather. Cant wait to go back.
author: Maria G.

description: I wanted to do a beer tasting and I typically like Speakeasy type of places. I came on a Friday and the place felt almost empty which I kind of like since I don't really care for crowds. The inside of the place was warm and cozy. They had several selections of beer that you can do a flight of. They do not have any food inside of the place which I like to have food if I'm drinking.  I tried several types of beer and didn't care for the beers except the darker ones and the Porter with Philz beans. I'm not much of a beer drinker! This is an ok place but I prefer sour beer and cocktails!
author: Courtney Y.

description: Awesome little find after Archimedes Banya! Wish it was a bit closer to the city but will definitely be coming back. Awesome decor as well!
author: Aaron S.

description:
I would rate these beers above average for craft beers. And they better be good, because while people do live around here, for most this is way out of the way.

But if you are going to go with the speakeasy motif, ditch the TV above the bar, it kills the vibe. You don't necessarily have to adopt the whole secret password stuff, but at least make the inside coherent by not having bright electronics.
author: John C.

description:
I was looking for some craft breweries to try out - and found a few that were not far away from my hotel by SFO. 

I visited Speakeasy on a Thursday night - it's a small place inside, not a lot of seating, and there was a good number of folks on hand enjoying their brews.

I ordered a tasting flight of four brews:

Tallulah Extra Pale Ale (5.6% ABV)
Vendetta IPA (7.6% ABV)
Double Daddy Blood Orange Imperial IPA (8.5% ABV)
California Love Imperial Red Ale (7.9% ABV)

I very much enjoyed the first three ales. The Imperial Red was kind of bland compared to the first three Ales. It's also possible that my taste buds were wrecked after the first three ales and I could not parse out the flavors...

The Double Daddy was super skunky - and I mean that in only the best possible way. It was my favorite of the four, followed by the Vendetta and then the Tallulah...

If you plan to pay via credit card - I believe the minimum is more than $10.00.

Cool little craft brewery! I'd visit here again!
author: Neal E.

description:
Wait, there is a brewery in Hunter's Point? I need to leave the comfort of the city? WORTH IT!

Finally made the trip to Speakeasy Ales & Lagers this past Sunday and was completely blown away by the experience here. My fiancé and I decided to take a nice bike ride out to Speakeasy to see what all the buzz was about.  Located south of the Dogpatch near the loading docks and old Piers Speakeasy is a bit off the beaten path.  Luckily, we came on an afternoon when they were holding a cool fundraiser and we were greeted at the front gates with blasting jazz music, people dressed up in 1920s style costumes, an outdoor magic show, oh and a bounce house! I was instantly hooked. From the moment we rode up the property the staff here was out of this world friendly.  The door guy greeted us and said we could safely lock up our bikes by the entrance of the brewpub and even suggested that they would be safe overnight (if we indulged in one too many). 

The property of the brewpub is quite large, a massive outdoor space with picnic tables, high tops and some corn hole to keep you occupied while sipping on some great beers.  Inside, this spot has a truly authentic 'speakeasy' decor.  Dimly lit bar with old wood paneling and some mix-matched vintage chairs and couches to lounge in.  The bar itself is quite small, only about 8 seats so get there early if you want to snag a table.  The bartenders inside were incredibly friendly, immediately handing us menus, answering any questions we had about various beer styles and all chatting/having a good time at work. I always like to see bartenders that actually look like they enjoy their job and this group of guys had a smile on their face all day, joking, chatting and having small talk with all the customers in the bar during the day. 

For beers we had the Vendetta IPA ($6), Blind Tiger Imperial IPA ($6), Tallulah Extra Pale Ale ($5), and Double Daddy DIPA ($5).  All were fantastic.  Speakeasy has a rotating selection of about 10+ drafts and you can purchase a handful of their limited release bottles at the tap room to take home and enjoy. Speakeasy also has a shuttle service on Friday of Giants games (with proof of ticket) you can grab some (more affordable) local beers before headed to the game in the complimentary shuttle. Also, they are part of the SF Brewers Guild Beer Shuttle - every third Wednesday the free shuttle takes you to a handful of local breweries including hosting events like meet the brew maker, etc.  A truly enjoyable experience at this gem of a tap room this weekend. Speakeasy has quickly become my new favorite brewery in the area and I can't wait to go back.
author: Kelsey B.

description:
Speakeasy, the first beer that made me fall in love with beer. Before that I was a naive and stupid girl who drank Heineken because that's what Asians usually bring to parties. I was not living until Big Daddy came into my life. Ever since that, Speakeasy has been my favorite brewery. 

Someone took me here for my first visit as a surprise and from then, I fell more in love with the brand. The bar, though small, is quite nice to chat with new people who love the beer as well. There's awesome decor. I wouldn't really recommend this place as a "first date" place, save this for a few dates in. Two communal-like room or for big groups then only a few seats in the bar area, but the outdoors area is open when there's an event!

I really like the option of having tasters. 5 tasters for $7 or so. Good way to taste all those beers you're on the fence about buying a 6pack/giant bottle over. 

There are a few snacks you can order, I haven't tried any yet, except a sample of the pretzel once. They also sell merchandise! 

If it's your first time, no matter what beers you choose as your tasters, choose Metropolis as one of them.
author: Cindy D.

description: On point local beers  sweet of da grid spot !! Would definitely comeback ... cute gear!! Yeah I'd recommend it.. worth checking out.
author: michelle r.

description:
My first time visiting the brewery and I loved it! We showed up around 430 on Friday afternoon. It was already busy but we were able to snag a seat in the corner at the bar. The selection of beers were awesome! And the environment was top notch. 

It was the brewmasters last day so the celebration all night was continuous with shots flowing. 

The staff were all friendly and helpful. Probably some of the nicest people ever. Didn't get thrown off as the crowd kept coming. Handled everything very well. My favorite was Molly! She was funny, filled up our drinks when we were getting low and had this attitude about her that everyone loved. Even the security guard outside was great. We were one of the last to leave and car was parked solo, he made sure to check on it and make sure it didn't get broken into. Two thumbs up for looking out bro!
author: Erica C.

description:
I'm partial to anything 1920's themed, so this place grabbed my attention right away when I was visiting San Francisco and looking for local breweries.

The location, according to our Uber Driver, was a little off the beaten path. It wasn't in the best part of the city. I honestly feel like that added to the secretive "speakeasy" vibe.

The decor was SO amazing- a slot in the door in true speakeasy style, a man to check you in at the door with a flashlight, some nice one-man-band music going on, low lighting and private room areas. It was love at first sight, really.

The beer made everything better, and of course this is the most important part of a brewery, really. Every beer my husband and I tried, we loved. I especially appreciated the Pop Gun Pilsner. Go for a flight, you get to pick any you'd like to try!

Definitely try this place if you are looking for breweries in San Francisco- you won't be disappointed!
author: Desirae E.

description:
Really cool taproom and some of the best beers in the city (especially for that price!!). It's a little out of the way but kinda makes it great since they aren't that crowded. They also had a taco vendor outside last time we went.
Favorites:
- Baby Daddy session IPA
- Saison (only sold at the taproom)
- Popgun pilsner
author: Sarah E.

description:
The new remodel is great, place looks sharp!  

Nice spaces inside to sit, as well as some park benches outside to sit/drink/eat at.

Beers, of course, are great.  I was already a fan before coming here, so the usuals that I drink were on point (had samplers): Baby Daddy Session IPA, Big Daddy IPA and Prohibition Ale.  The new release of the Blind Tiger Triple IPA was outstanding, very smooth and easy to drink for a ~10.7% beer; was only going to have one, but had to have two 10 oz. pours of the Blind Tiger since it was so good.

You can get beer to go (cans/bottles/crowlers etc.), so some good take home options after you find which ones are your favorites.

Service was friendly and good.

Will definitely return.
author: Deon C.

description:
There beers are kinda like the neighborhood the brewery is in. Soulful, strong, big bold flavors just a real quality product. I had some seasonal pumpkin ale and some ipa's. There was a hot dog cart if you were hungry. 

Came in for their Friday happy hour, dollar off (already great prices of their beer). Parking was plentiful and pretty easy. It's more in the industrial part of Bayview so you don't have to worry about any riff raff hanging out on the corner. 

The taproom isn't that big and since there was a warriors game it got crowded quick. The only women there were the bartenders so it was a major d.....ude fest. I mean, I went to the only all boys high school in the city so I know how that goes. Most of my friends then were from the Mission/Vis Valley/Excelsior/Cow Palace area (not exactly the Marina) so I'm used to kinda hoodish crowds. Here the crowd just wasn't my vibe, some were even more hoodish and some.... yeah just not really my crowd. 

Speakeasy is kinda in the middle of nowhere and more of a destination, you can't really barhop/pubcrawl from it but I might return to do a brewery tour or when they have live music in the summer.
author: Earl G.

description:
I guess I am lucky that the Speakeasy Ales & Lagers is not within one mile from my home... because if it was, I would be here every other day sipping on delicious crafts and obtaining the beer belly, which definitely doesn't help the case for my nonexistent new years resolutions.

As I am a sucker for stouts, I just HAD to come when they hosted the Yelp event here last month. I really liked the vibe, and loved the cat that lurked around here. I believe I tried everything on their beer selection, and I have to say my favorites were Syndicate, Scarface and Black Hand (chocolate milk stout)... obviously, biased because I like strong stouts. My friend's favorite was the BBA (barrel aged) Scarface because she likes the strong taste.

The staff here was so nice and accommodating. I will definitely be back, if I find someone who is willing to make the trip with me here. 

Recommended? Yesss, don't come with a big-ass group though. I think 2-4 is a good number.
author: Solongo B.

description:
This is a really cool place to get beers! Very positive and fast paced environment. Went on a Saturday and it was packed! They have a lot of corn-hole games set up outside, and there is a lot of seating inside. 

The beer here is great! The blood orange one was super tasty :) we also got a pretzel, which was good but it wasn't warm like I thought it would be. If you want mustard you have to buy a whole jar of it too-$5(but it's made with there beer in it- and looks pretty yummy). 

Love the little black cat that was wandering around!! 

They also have parking!! Thank god! I hate dealing with street parking.
author: Hayley D.

description:
We have been here several times and it's always tough to leave. Love their set up, their pourers and the changing seasonal offerings. My favorite is getting a sampler and then finish with Double Daddy. Be sure to eat before you come because that will certainly give you a good buzz. 
M-F happy hour and Firkin Friday is on point. Haven't made it here on the weekend but they offer tours and other events.
author: Damaris F.

description:
They just started doing beer tours again at Speakeasy Ales & Lagers so while in SF, we went.  It's all the way out in Hunter's Point but the tour is less than $8 and you get 2 tasters of beer while you're there.  You also have the option of sitting at the bar and ordering beers as well.  We rode the MUNI out to Hunter's Point from Union Square.  It's about 45 minutes by bus so if you have alternate transportation, take that.  We were dropped outside the building and walked up.  For a Saturday afternoon, the place was still empty but I imagine that's because it's in the middle of nowhere.  They have corn hole out in the parking lot if you're so inclined, and the tasting room and bar area is dimly decorated.  I tried a pumpkin ale for both of my tasters, and one was actually served out of a giant pumpkin!  It was okay for beer but again, I'm not much of a beer drinker.  

There were a few people at the bar when we arrived and some of them went on the tour with us.  It wasn't my first brewery tour but it was cool to see and hear about their process.  Our tour guide admitted that it was his first day giving tours but welcomed any questions we might have.  Our tour group had a few questions but we were fine just listening.  We didn't stay long because we wanted to be back in Union Square to go back to Mikkeller and finish out our stay in SF.
author: Trina D.

description: Beer is good, decent price for the pours. I just wish they allowed dogs inside the brewery. I love beer, but love my dogs more. My favorite thing is to bring my dogs to breweries, however, with speakeasy, this isn't possible unless you want your dog to sit outside. For dog lovers there are other breweries which are much better.
author: Nicholas K.

description: I recently rented out one of the small rooms to host a birthday. The tasting room manager, Nick, was awesome to work with. It was a great space, great beer, and the price was excellent. Would definitely recommend as a spot for a small group.
author: Laurel C.

description: Great job on redesign!  Staff is great and beer is on point.  It is a new favorite neighborhood spot.
author: Brad L.

description: One of my favorite places in this part of town. The workers and basically everyone there are always very friendly. Just a really great vibe. Very dark in there but nicely decorated. They offer a nice selection of beers. Usually I just order the big daddy or the double daddy IPA. Those two are probably my favorite ones. They also have beers for purchase and even refills in growlers. There's also outdoor seating and games that people can play. Simply a really great place to hang out with large and small groups.
author: Annie H.

description:
I've been spending a bit more time at Speakeasy and I've got to give an additional nod of respect to Jeff and Xavier. These guys make this place feel "like home." Further, they have extensive knowledge about the beer, and about beer in general. I love hearing about what I'm drinking, and these members of the team will lend an ear and offer their expertise, which is much appreciated.

Speaking of beer.... I've noticed they frequently rotate the taps here. I was legitimately excited when I saw Metropolis was back on tap this week. I like knowing that there might be a surprise on the tap list when I walk in the door. I will continue to visit Speakeasy with frequency.
author: Alex E.

description:
Beer, beer, beer, I love beer. 

Boy does this place make some great beer. Plus they have a super cool speakeasy style tasting room. Belly up or hang out on a comfy couch and sip on some tasty suds. Go on a quick tour, grab some bottles to-go, and chat it up with the staff, everyone was quite friendly. I've been here a handful of times and each visit has been great.

Drink up San Francisco, you've got one great brewery here.
author: Justin C.

description:
By far my favorite place to grab beers. I look forward to coming here on Tuesdays because it's a hit or miss on how busy they are. The bartenders make my day they are all goofy, fun and knowledgable of the beer selections.  They play roll the dice on Tuesdays, you roll the dice and whatever number you roll is how much you pay for your beer. They have seasonal beers and barrel aged. Great experience overall. Recommended to come if you are looking for a chill spot :) 

DOG FRIENDLY !!!
author: Gabriela C.

description: LOVE this spot! The decor/ambiance is completely on par with the brews. Fantastic IPAs for days & bourbon barrel aged stouts/ales
author: Lindsay K.

description: Blessed to be able to live right down the street from this place. Love the vibe. Beer is incredible!!
author: Mikey S.

description:
Came here twice. Once was several years ago when it first opened and we were able to drink and walk through the actual distillery area and there were food trucks outside. Fun times!

Second time was much more recent and was still a great time. The actual bar/lounge area was dimly lit and it wasn't overly crowded for a Saturday night. Easy to find a table, easy to find parking. It's great!

And, there are board and card games. We ended up playing Cards Against Humanity and that was fun. We stayed for almost 3 hours, drinking and playing. It was nice and chill.

Though, to be honest, it's kind of in the middle of nowhere. At least for now. So if you're going for a beer at Speakeasy, you're basically *really* going for *several* beers at Speakeasy.

Fun space. I'll definitely be back.
author: Sandy T.

description:
The San Francisco Brewery Tour...STOP #1

The owner, Mr. Blackcat, was kind of a punk and did a swell job of ignoring me and my bros...but his staff was nice enough.  Yeah Mr. Blackcat...go crawl back into the hold you came out of!

Being MLK weekend, I started off with the four black beers: Porter, Milk Stout, Imperial Stout, and I think a Black IPA? Am I drunk already? They were all tasty, though all kind of tasted the same?  Also tried something called "Unbroken" and some of their Belgians...IT TASTES SO GOOD WHEN IT HITS YOUR LIPS!  I'll stop shouting...I'm only about 20oz of beer in so far...

Go home Chun...you're drunk!
author: Chun P.

description: Really nice space and friendly service. Their beers are good although I'm more into light ones so the saisson hit the spot. It's nice to come after work, especially since 12 oz. pours are $4 and 16 oz. are only $5.
author: Naomi S.

description: Ricky is so nice. I this place is my favorite brewery in SF. I can't remember the bouncer's name, but he's great too. Lots of IPAs here. The outside portion of the brewery has corn hole and picnic tables. The door to get in is just as you'd expect.
author: Kaz K.

description:
I was recently fortunate to stop here for my first-time at a Yelp Elite event. I had always wanted to check it out, but being on Evans Ave it's not exactly a place I walk by on a regular basis. 

So glad I went to this event, as it exposed to me a super friendly staff and delicious selection of beers you can't always find at your local haunt. I tried some more common brews I had been holding off on (Prohibition and Double Daddy) but also some varieties I wouldn't normally go for. Everything was great and I came out with a pleasant buzz after the fact.

I may not be able to make it over here on a regular basis, but will definitely bring friends this way if they are beer aficionados.
author: Jon T.

description: Although this place is a little out there, I would definitely recommend coming here! The staff was so super helpful and nice (shoutout to the bouncer who shares the same birthday as me and was just delightful). The beer is very good and the interior and decor is super cool as well. I would definitely check this place out
author: Rachel N.

description:
I got to check this place out as part of a Yelp Elite event.  It was certain located in an area that  looked more like an industrial complex, so it definitely had the "hidden away" feel to it.  The brewery had a good selection of beers that were more hops-centered than other types.  I tried most of what's available on the list and all were pretty smooth and flavorful. The chocolate-milk stout was my favorite of the bunch. 

As for the atmosphere the brewery is definitely dark, but feels private.  It's not a place for large groups, but well-suited for a pair of people. We also were given samples of sandwiches by Dusty Buns, which was a nice compliment to the event that day. 

I'd certainly come back again to check this place out.
author: Nick A.

description: So happy Nick and team is breathing new life into this place! Great vibes, very well done decor and of course DELICIOUS and solid selection of beer. Great outdoor area to hang if you want some fresh air too. I just stopped in for a quick beer but was completely welcomed and so happy to come across this gem
author: Caitlin O.

description:
8/31/14: Came here on an epic beer run over the Labor Day weekend.  And after hitting up many breweries starting Sat and ending Sun, including Lagunitas, Russian River, Rogue, Mikkeller, Monk's Kettle, Cellarmaker, this place was our last stop.  That was a TON of beer, and to be honest I was looking forward to drinking some soda instead ha ha, but here we were...

After an epic weekend of drinking, this beer was still AWESOME.  Yeah, some of the flavors I didn't like so much, but all were very flavorful, and some were extremely good...

1. Double Daddy: a very flavorful IPA with a very rich body.  This was my favorite.

2. Harvey Milk: smoky as expected for a very dark beer.  Medium richness and very satisfying.

I also got, but didn't know which was which in the tasting lineup:

3. Tallulah
4. Metropolis Lager

AND... all of this was SIX DOLLARS!!!  WTF!!!  I have never heard of a sampler that cheap.  Crazy.

Another noteworthy event happened: the 49ers were there on Sun hanging out it appeared, to celebrate one of their buddies' bday.  Sorry, I'm not a football follower so I dunno who was who, but I just wanted to say that when we walked in we didn't know they were pro players--but many of them came over to say hi and have a few drinks and gave hugs and stuff.  Some very pretty girls also came over later on and told us we needed to try these beers and gave us glasses.  We honestly had no idea who these people were 'till later, which goes to show how amazingly friendly and humble they were.  I think one of them even told my friend, "we should hang out."  Ha ha, k.  Oh, and one of them was really good at piano!

So... beer was excellent, the price was simply out of this world, and the company--the best.

5/5

#pub #bar #beer #brewery
author: Dean C.

description:
Dropped by Speakeasy upon arrival to SF. 

Creative decor. Isolated location with parking. Friendly staff!
author: Elaine D.

description:
Speakeasy Ales & Lagers seems like it is in the middle of nowhere, with a relatively empty parking lot. As you walk to the entrance you will feel like you are about to enter a real Prohibition era speakeasy, sliding peephole in the door and all. The tap room itself has a dark and mysterious vibe, and is relatively quiet compared to most tap rooms.

The beer itself is very tasty; most of the brews are very hop-centric. Some of my favorites include the Double Daddy Imperial IPA and the Baby Daddy Session IPA. The Big Daddy IPA and the Prohibition Ale are also very good.

Prices for a pint of one of the many Speakeasy ales and lagers are extremely reasonable, probably being the cheapest I have ever seen for craft beer. Check out Speakeasy Ales & Lagers if you have a car in the San Francisco area and are a fan of hoppy beers!
author: Lindsey D.

description:
Friendly bartenders and brewers, good beers, reasonable prices for SF, Speakeasy is an all around win.

On Saturdays they have lawn games, brewery tours, and tasty snacks available. This is just a tap house, so if you are looking for a substantial meal, look elsewhere. However if you want good beer and good company, definitely check this place out. 

The inside is dark and cozy, not a huge place. But on a nice day or night, they have picnic tables outside if you prefer some more room.
author: Meredith H.

description:
Not the coolest brewery I've ever been to, but it's hard to compare places in San Francisco to places down in San Diego where everything is cheaper and more spacious.

Speakeasy is definitely worth checking out, though!  Hunter's Point is supposed to be sketchy, but it didn't seem like it at all when I went.  There's PLENTY of room for parking, so take your car!  I took the bus, but it wasn't quite as close to the muni as it looked on a map.

My favourite beer was the Scarlett Red Rye. The Big Daddy IPA was another favourite, but the rest were a little forgettable. Whatever. I don't know that much about beer anyway. It's a nice weekend activity, so just swing by!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Love Speak Easy beers why...why not, it's great.

SF brewery, great flavors, right here on Evans stret!
Big daddy
Baby daddy
Pop gun
Oh damn...GOD FATHER !
...
..
.
GOOD NIGHT..LOL
author: Matt J.

description: First time at the new taproom and the service still measures up to the quality. I have loved speakeasy since I turned 21 and they haven't missed a step since. Speakeasy is undoubtedly one of the best American breweries that can be found on the west coast.
author: Dallas H.

description:
great environment. 

great staff. 

great beer.

parking is easy. 

location is in the middle of nowhere which is a relief not having to be in the mess of san francisco. 

super clean. 

the end.
author: Nicole A.

description:
I can't believe I haven't reviewed them yet! I love their beer! Payback porter is always my fave go to here. That is one seriously delicious beer! I was pleasantly surprised by Talullah and Scarlett. I can't say not to a Big Daddy and the Prohibition. They had a special brew back in May, I think it was international orange? Can't remember the name but it was amazing. I'm really just in love with their beer.

The only reason I dock them a star is how dark the new tap room is. If you come in from the sun, it takes some time to actually see anything inside. If you go on a Sunday, it will be pretty empty so the risk is minimal. I've also seen people dump a beer when they put it on a table with a very uneven surface.

You can walk there from the T which is nice but it's not in the best hood so keep your eyes open.
author: Tera K.

description:
My fiancée took me to speakeasy for a my birthday and i must say, this has got to be one of the most enjoyable brewery experience. Ive been to numerous breweries and have never felt so welcome. 

As we walked in, it was pretty dark, well coming from outside. Once your eyes adjusted, Speakeasy was pretty interesting, lots of things to look at. They have a bar and about 3 or 4 small type living-rooms that people can sit at. 

Molly was the friendliest beer-tenders I have ever ran across. She was very knowledgeable with the beers speakeasy was serving, with molly being experienced with beer, she even spoke about Different spots and beers in San Diego, since she had resided there before, she gave us some good spots to visit. 

Its cool that both beer-tenders were giving us the history of the Black cat, named BrewCat.. or something.. but the cat being there for 13-15 years is pretty cool. The protection of Speakeasy. 

Flights were for any 4 for $6 ( pretty decently priced for "any"). 
My flight:
Double daddy- imperial ipa
Suspect-belgian golden
Old godfather -barley wine
Payback - porter.

**all the beers i had were good. they were all tasty and not watered down or even had the slightest taste of "eehhhhh". My favorite was the Barley wine(old godfather) i just loved the taste and at 9.5% ill give it my thumbs up. 

Check out the medicine cabinet for good deals too.. =)

When in SF, i would definately make speakeasy my first stop. Thanks Speakeasy and Molly, Definately started out my birthday right!
author: Jeffrey C.

description:
My all-time favorite brewery that produces the best IPA: Big Daddy and Double Big Daddy
Surprisingly in the nicer area of Hunter's Point. If this will be your first time going here and you are taking an Uber out there. Don't think your driver is taking you to the middle of no where and is about to kidnap you. This location is in the cuts!

+The tap room is a really cool spot to hang out with friends.
+Bartenders were friendly.
+Variety of IPA's, stouts, and other types
+I went to their anniversary last June, and got to try different IPA's and other types.
author: Ron D.

description:
Infamously known for brewing the Big Daddy Prohibition series of beers, this spot is definitely a go-to for any beer lover. The squad and I came here for a birthday party and not only did we enjoy ourselves with an excessive amount of beer, but we got to go on the "tasting" tour as well. For 7 bucks, I would definitely suggest to skip the tour and stick with the consumption of the beer in the drinking areas. 
As for the facility itself, I found it to be a tad bit cramped on the inside. There's 3 different vintage parlor type seating areas where you can sit on couches. Luckily, our group was large enough that we were able to snatch one up for ourselves. The bar also has games like Jenga that you can borrow to keep yourself entertained. I would suggest at least putting in one more restroom, because just having a single occupancy restroom for guys and gals is not cool. Overall, this spot is definitely worth checking out at least once in your lifetime.
author: Cristal C.

description: When it comes to atmosphere & theme, Speak Easy takes the cake! The dim lit rooms & decor just add to the experience, makes you feel like you stepped into a time machine straight to the 1920's. The staff is super friendly, definitely comes in the clutch pre-gaming before a Giants' game. When available, the "Payback Pumpkin Pie Porter" is one of my all-time favorites! You just can't go wrong taking a trip to Speak Easy.
author: Anthony A.

description: Great little place for some really tasty beer! We're drinking a Suspect and a Suds. Yum! Will be back when I'm in San Francisco again.
author: Susan R.

description:
This is hands down my favorite place in Hunter's Point.  They have an amazing tap collection.  My personal favorites are the big daddy and double daddy IPAs, although the baby daddy IPA is also good.  I'm an IPA guy, myself, if you can't tell already.  They also offer flights, growlers, and cans for sale, as well as a tour you can do.  

The staff is super friendly, from the bartenders to security.  I've received free beer shots on a couple occasions.  They also have 2 big rooms that you can use and even rent out.  Sometimes they'll have live music and corn hole too.  They're dog/cat friendly depending on temperament of course. 

It's called Speakeasy, so there's also a little red button hidden on one of the walls, just in case of any police raids.  DO NOT PUSH THE BUTTON! I know you want to push it now, but don't.  Bad things happen if you push the button.  I can't even begin to describe the terrible things I've seen when someone pushed it.
author: Eric L.

description: After a failed attempt at playing mini golf at the pier couple of friends and I decided to drop by speakeasy for a drink. It was around 8pm on a Thursday and the bar was fairly empty. They had good selection of beers on tap as well as bottled, ranging from fruity beers, coffee beer and even chocolate milk beer. Great atmosphere, great beer, friendly crowd and they have two corn hole games out front! Such a simple game but I gotta say it was pretty fun.
author: Linz C.

description:
What a cool, low key place! It is totally tucked away and in a random building. Pretty much like an old fashioned speakeasy! 
My boyfriend is in love with speakeasy and drinks the big daddy at least once a week. I was looking forward to the chance of trying some other beers they make. 
I got a sampler which is a pretty good deal at only six bucks! The beers I had were all good, however none really knocked me off my socks. Although, I absolutely hated the coconut smoked porter. I couldn't even drink it! It tasted like liquid ribs. Gross...
The beer-tenders were pretty nice and funny. Service was a tad slow, but it was busy in there. 
The winning star was the bar cat named kitty. He was an awesome little black kitty with a voice. Such a cool thing to have in a bar.
author: Issy D.

description:
Really nice set up. Great for coming and having good conversations with friends and just chill.

They have jenga, cards, chess, and dominoes you can play.

Great beer selections and they have a sampler tray you can request your favorite kind of beer and they bring you a variety.

Really friendly staff. I asked for pins, they didn't have any but they have me awesome stickers! 
Looking forward to coming here more often.
author: Kat R.

description:
It may be located in the middle of nowhere-SF, but it's dark and mysterious inside with many a nook and many a cranny. They do tasting flights and a tulip glass is $5. That's a pretty good price to while away a morning I mean afternoon. Oh, and I'm a fan of their BBA Scarface. 

There is also a beer cat who lives here.
author: Jonathan Y.

description:
Best bartender best security guard ever. This was my first time visiting San Fran and this place was on my bucket list and they totally nailed it with their beer and customer service. 

I walked out with a jug of beer and posters and a great smile on Fourth of July :) look forward to coming here again in the near future.
author: Daisy R.

description:
Speakeasy is a great place to come by if you're in SF. Be warned though, you'll be a ways out. 

Big Daddy and Double Daddy IPA are two of my favs! I've grabbed a couple growlers here before as well. Reasonably priced. They have some great seasonal beers that come out - just check the website!

You can also buy 24 packs here - my brother and I have done a price comparison and its relatively (understandably) cheaper than picking em up at the grocery store. 

Ambiance: I really enjoy the front end of the space, it's dark, has little private areas to sit with a group of friends, definitely gives you that speakeasy feel. The back has a lot of open space and an additional bar as well - just be forewarned, it's not very warm back there so if you come in the evening or the winter time and get chilly easily like I do, make sure you got some layers (you're in SF after all). 

Parking: they have a lot that is small, but I've never not found parking. 

Not much in the way of food to go by around here so be prepared. Also you're not going to be walking around to other places, Speakeasy is somewhat isolated in that regard.
author: Tania K.

description:
Awesome beer factory tour. Speakeasy makes the very popular (in 30+ states) Big Daddy IPA and other varieties.

The tour is $7 and can be booked online ahead of time. I recommend it to learn how beer is made. It only lasts 20 mins ish and you only get 1 free small shot of beer (wish they gave more), but the beer they serve before and after (in a great environment and setting) is really good and really cheap. $3 prohibition IPA's all Saturday. $6 for 4 you pick it tastings, great deals. 

Plus, they have food (specialty sausages) come in on site too, and cornhole outside.

Learned a decent amount about how beer is made in the vats, kegging, bottling, etc. Plus, good drinks and an awesome staff.
author: Chuck N.

description: Good beer and good ambiance. I have been seeing this beer in San Diego and never tried it. I'm glad I had the opportunity to visit the brewery. The bartender was super nice and helped me coordinate my flight. They had a biker event there and there were two bands giving much funk. I thoroughly enjoyed my visit and the beer!
author: Rin M.

description:
Who would have thought that a great little tap room would be situated in this neighborhood of industrial parks? They have lots of parking, but seeing as there is not much to do around this area, I would recommend just going with a tour or something, that way you can just get in and out. We didn't realize the location was not great so we got stuck here for longer than we wanted to be while we sobered up to drive. 

We came here mid-day during the week and the place still had a good number of people in it. Overall, I was pretty satisfied with all of the varieties that I tried. I tend to go for the light belgians and theirs did not disappoint (forgot the name of it though). 

The prices were pretty good for SF, service was friendly, and the place was nicely decorated. I would probably go again!
author: Samantha T.

description:
So I've been wanting to try Speakeasy brewery for several years now! I've been drinking their beers for almost 9 years now, started with the prohibition ale and double daddy IPA. 

We we found ourselves in the Mission so this place wasn't too far from the area so we too, a quick Lyft over to the brewery. Once we were dropped off we found ourselves in a small, dark, very crowded tap room. That was the worst thing about our experience was how small it is and it can get busy very quickly. Lucky for us everyone was nice enough and I made my way to the bar and orders a few beers. Fell in love with their pumpkin porter and their black IPA. Which they would bottle or can these, they were that good!!

Met some really cool people at the bar while we're there. The good thing about a small bar is it kinda forces you to talk to people. That was a good thing. They had a tv in the bar and it was tuned to the Warriors game which was real fu when everyone was cheering them on. 

Overall Speakeasy's tap room was small and dark, but the beer they were serving has to be best in town.  I would love to come here more often on my SF trips and try more of their speciality beers!
author: Aaron A.

description:
One of the best breweries I've been too. Love that the beer here is very affordable and bartenders are friendly.  It's just kinda out of the way, but that's part of its charm. 
There use to be brew kitty but she has passed away. :( super fun having a cat around tho! 
My fav drink is the baby daddy and syndicate no. 3. Check them out! I usually do the flights for $7 (5 five or 4 drinks? In a flight).
author: Kat C.

description: I stopped by on Saturday afternoon for tour. Speakeasy is a brand new brewery with stainless steel and titanium tanks. Clean and sparkling, Italian made brewing system. The taproom is a little small but has a good vibe for Speakeasy. I was disappointed that they only gave one sample. I expected a few since most breweries try to showcase their different styles and usually include a sampler flight for paid tours.
author: David F.

description:
I love the feeling of walking into a brewery for the first time. I came here with my friend on a Sunday late afternoon, and it was practically empty. I parked in the lot out front, which is probably the best way to get here, since I'm sure public transportation would take much longer.

I was not overly impressed by the decor or the bartenders at Speakeasy, but I'm glad that the awesomeness of the beers made up for it. You can sit at the bar or on couches and benches around the place. The baristas were engaged in conversation with apparently more interesting customers and made it seem like serving us was an interruption to their laughing fun. That was annoying. Even the "bouncer" was the friendliest guy in the whole place. But really, I'm here for the beer.

Double Daddy IPA is my favorite. Well actually any of their IPAs are good. I love the whole theme of the Speakeasy series. If you love it enough, you can even get bombers or growlers to go! I hear they are planning to expand this place, so their tap room is currently unavailable, but I can't wait to go back and check that out.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
I was really sad that my brief experience here was less than stellar. My husband and I were in downtown sf for vacation and I really wanted to stop here and try some tasty beers. The tap room is in a industrial area with nothing else around; our taxi driver continuously warned us that the area wasnt safe. When we walked in, the place was totally empty except for a few customers bellied up to the bar. I understand that the giants game was on, but there was honestly no music or friendliness or any type of "ambiance". We felt really out of place and didn't feel quite welcome. We had one round of ipas and left.

This place gets two stars because the beer was really good, too bad the place felt unwelcoming.
author: christin f.

description:
Ruben loves his beer and luckily, so does his Bay Area-local cousin. We visited on a Saturday afternoon and there was a good amount of people in the Tap Room. Fortunately, there was a high table and large comfy chairs available near the entrance. Otherwise, we would have been standing. The beers on tap available was written on the chalkboard door behind the bar. None of their "Usual Suspects" (the beers they brew year-round) were on tap, but available via bottle. 

They offered two beers from their "Limited Series" (small batch releases) and all three beers from their "Infamous Series" (brewed in single batches and they boast are their "boldest and most elusive releases"). Ruben got a sampler of The Informant (Elderflower Saison), Double Daddy (Imperial IPA), Scarface (Imperial Stout), Untouchable (Nelson IPA), and The Suspect (Belgian Golden Ale). They also ordered pints of The Blind Tiger (Imperial IPA) and Harvey Milk (Milk Stout). Ruben's favorites were the two Imperial IPAs: Double Daddy and The Blind Tiger.

The Tap Room is a really cool hang out! Along with the bar area, and high tables, there are two separate rooms with comfortable seating as well. There's also touring available via reservation (information and schedules on the website). And if you visit on Fridays (4-9pm), you can hang out in the Brewhouse Bar which is all ages (Tap Room is 21+).
author: Amelinda L.

description:
Great beer overall! 

Overall we all ordered:
double daddy imperial IPA
Prohibition Amber Ale
Big Daddy

The above beer hit the spot! We will be coming here again!
author: Jay B.

description:
Speakeasy - home of the Big Daddy. 

Came by here during the Yelp 10-Year Celebration weekend as part of the SF Craft Brewery Tour. We were treated to a tasting of about 4 different beers and given a quick tour of the brewery. 

As a brewery, you have a lot of things to chose from. I'm not going to get into the exact beers as they've been discussed a lot in other reviews (and let's face I'm not an expert anyway), but needless to say Speakeasy is more than just being the place that makes "Big Daddy IPA". While there I tried the Bourbon Barrel, Untouchable, Prohibition Ale, and Tallulah, and I'd say my favorite was probably the Prohibition, though the Bourbon Barrel packed quite a bunch (10.5 abv!). 

As a bar, Speakeasy is a pretty intimate setting, as it's a little on the small side but really makes up for it by having a bunch of friendly bartenders who really know their beer. Their decision to open up a taproom in front was definitely a great idea, as I'll fondly think back to my experience there anytime I'm drinking one of their beers. 
 
Bayview-Hunters Point is definitely out of the way - but as bartenders here recommend - just take an Uber. If you split a ride I'm sure it's not too bad, and the upside of having a different kind of HH/drinking experience seems worth it anyway. Plus it's always nice to support a local brewery. Definitely would recommend.
author: Brian S.

description: This place is cool! I wish it wasn't so far away though. There's a back bar that has less people if you want to bypass the line.
author: Angela L.

description: Love the new remodel for the tasting room.  It's a little on the small side, so can get crowded at times.  But, the vintage/rustic decor looks great and fits well with the industrial environment. Like many brewery tap rooms, there are always special beers on offer that you can't get anyplace else.  Of course, it's still in Hunter's Point and a bit out of the way.  There's nothing else in the area, so Speakeasy is really a destination that, unless you have a designated driver, requires a Uber to get to.  But the beer and crowd are great, so it's worth the effort to get there.
author: Bryce B.

description:
Hit up this spot on a trip to San Francisco. 
Friendly, knowledgeable bartenders and friendly patrons. The guy next to me offered us a sip from his Bourbon barrel aged beer...I forgot what it was called, but it was delicious.
The brew is amazing quality. We ordered 5 beers. 
2 Big Daddys and an Old Grandfather, Pop Gun, and a Double Daddy ran us only $22!
author: Lauren S.

description:
Love this place ! wanted to check it out for a while. At least 15 different bees on tap that you can try 4 for $6. HH until 5pm. CC accepted. 

Great staff, ambianace and energy, fun crowd.
author: Magda G.

description:
I came for a Brewery Tour during SFMade week. When I saw there was a tour there, I was excited as I thought they never have tours. When I got there I asked when they started doing tours and they said they started when they opened their Tap Room about a year ago. 

There's a parking lot and ample street parking in a very industrial area. The entrance leads you into their Tap Room which I loved the love decor of. It has cool wallpaper, decorations, and Speakeasy elements like a sliding peep hole in the front door and a red emergency buzzer in case of a raid. It all throws back to their origins of how they started up w/o any proper permits and starting selling their beer to local bars under the table. 

The brewery tour was super informal. The bartender mentioned that someone called in sick, so when we asked where we should go for the tour, it was news to him that there was even a tour. He ended up leading it and it started quite a bit late, which he said was usual since most people don't arrive on time. 

They have Happy Hour on weekdays from 4-6 pm with $3 pints for their flagship beers. They also have some of their seasonal and specialty brews on the menu. 

You can bring your beer on the tour and you'll see the staff all have a beer in their hand while working. This has a real authentic feel vs. other more corporate breweries. You can tell the people here love their job and the casual relaxed atmosphere. 

The only bummer was that unlike most other brewery tours, there's no free beer tastes included. The tour is free though. 

On Friday, they also throw a weekly food truck party from 4 -9 pm with often times live music. They occasionally throw Saturday parties as well. There's even a disco ball in the brewery.
author: Rebecca G.

description:
My friends and I were there when they opened on Sunday.

We got to try all beers, and I felt like I couldn't decided which one was favorite because everything was equally great (okay.. I lied. I am a IPA lover and loved their Big Daddy and Double Daddy... and unfiltered one tasted best in my opinion.)

Decoration inside was really cool. There were two separate sitting areas plus bar. Maybe it was too early, because instead of any music, they were playing inception on TV. I kinda wish they didn't tho... the movie was way too loud.

The guy bartender was nice, but the tall, dark hair one was really really nice (she totally looks like Deborah from Dexter... maybe she really was? haha just kidding). We were buying some of their merchandise, and she was helpful and patient with us trying out some shirts and asking a bunch of questions. She wrapped everything nicely for our plane ride, and even hooked us up with some free posters and stickers. Thanks again!

I wished I could stay there all afternoon... had to buy bombers to bring back home some goodness. Hopefully I can go back one day.
author: Ann H.

description:
This place is awesome! Although it may be a little out of the way, it's definitely worth the extra drive. We stopped in on a rainy Sunday and it wasn't super busy. We got our beers right away and were able to snag a whole section of the place to ourselves away from those watching whatever football game happened to be on (sorry - I'm a hockey fan). The decor is dark, cozy, and in-line with their whole theme.

The employees (I wish I remembered their names!) were so friendly and more than willing to talk about beer - even ones from other breweries! I ended up buying one of their shirts that the female bartender happened to be wearing. 

I'm a big fan of Amber Ales so I tried the Prohibition, but I found that I liked Scarlett just a tad better. I was also able to try some of the Black Hand Chocolate Milke Stout...yum! 

I wish I lived closer so I could come here more often!
author: Katie T.

description:
I hadn't been back to Speakeasy since they opened up the taproom and now it's better than ever!  In the dimly lit taproom, you get your beer in a glass and grab a seat either at the bar or in one of the 2 adjacent rooms (great for groups), while listening to a good selection of classic rock.  Alternatively, on the other side you can still get a beer in a plastic cup and mingle amidst the barrels or out on the patio (though there's no more free popcorn).

Of course the beer was good, as usual.  $5 during non-happy hour.  I've always been a fan of the Payback porter and decided to try the Scarface imperial stout and the Double Daddy IPA.  The Scarface was fine - didn't pack as much coffee flavor as I had hoped, but the Double Daddy was excellent!  Hoppy, floral, aromatic, and crisp.  My only regret was ordering it too late so I couldn't savor it for longer before they kicked us out at 9pm.

And lastly, I wanted to mention that I biked here and was able to lock up to the handrail right at the entrance, so I wasn't too worried about theft.  Not that Evans St appears shady anyways...
author: Beatrice W.

description: Had a fabulous time.  Great company and the Syndicate 3 was amazing.  Very friendly brewery and dog friendly.  Have to go back soon.
author: Kim S.

description:
Five stars for ambiance.  They have really done a lot with this space, making it look like a true Speakeasy (or at least what I imagine one looked like).  There are a few semi-private tables where you can enjoy a beer with your lovah, or a group of friends.  There is also a nice bar area where you can chat with the friendly and knowledgeable bartenders.  A lot of the pictures here on Yelp are from before the remodel.  It no longer has the "industrial" look that appears in the photos.  

Despite what people say, I don't think it is hard to get to at all.  There is a bus stop across the street, and the muni station is only .5 miles down the road.  I didn't feel unsafe walking around in the area at all.  Plus, there is plenty of parking (if you actually own a car in SF).

The beers are all good, but I didn't think any were a stand-out great beer.  They are all something I would drink if available, but not something I would seek-out. 

Make sure to check the website for the hours before you go, they are only open limited hours- mostly in the afternoon/early evening.  Closed Mondays.
author: Jocelyn A.

description:
Though my 1st time ever out to Speakeasy was for the Yelp Field Trip Launch Party, I learned quite a bit about this place that night. A lot of what I picked up was because I arrived early & stayed well after the Yelp party was over.

Getting in early, I went to their taproom. Decked out in deep rich wood accents, this is the type of taproom that Ron Burgundy would admire. With a few featured beers being on $3 Happy Hour special, it was a place my wallet took a liking to as well.

After the Yelp event in their brewhouse, which makes a fine event space, I ended up talking to some longtime regulars of Speakeasy. It seems the handsome taproom is relatively new & part of recent expansion. Growth can be good.

The regulars also reminisced of a simpler Speakeasy where taps were only in the brewhouse & how there was a token system for getting beers to drink. The beers were cheaper back then too. Growth can have some growing pains.

From the stories of back then to what I experienced of the now, I think Speakeasy is heading in a good direction. Ideally, they add some kind of permanent on-site food option (it's OK to bring your own food) while keeping the $3 Happy Hour beers.
author: John M.

description: Nice place to hang out with friends for drinks. This place is strictly a bar and they don't serve any food. They have a variety of beers on tap, so I would suggest ordering a flight to try a little bit of everything. The Double Down knocked me on my ass!
author: Amy L.

description:
Ahh yes, Speakeasy as in das speakeasy deustch.

Which of course is German for do you like beer? 

I'm kidding but they are not, their beer is no joking matter. They got the good brews out here in Da Bayview in a locale that is intimate yet industrial and all jazzed up for a trip to the Roaring 20's.

They got different kinds of beer for all lovers of micro-brew. Porters and stouts for the dark beer lovers like myself. Belgium browns for those that want it rich and malty. Extra Extra Extra Pale for those that like to be round-housed to the face with hops. 

Thanks Speakeasy.
author: R J.

description:
I am definitely a fan.  I loved the prices of the beers and they were good.  My only complaint was some of the staff were a little standoff-ish. I just moved to the neighborhood and had been super excited to check it out and didn't feel the neighborhood welcome.  

I will come again with my fiance and let her decide.  Can't beat though the $6 - 4 taster flight.
author: Raja D.

description:
So what's up.

Though I don't drink beer - I am all about Speakeasy Brewery.

It's soooo San Francisco  - from the Speakeasy Speakeasy designed by Kelly Malone, to the hands on tours provided by their incredible and personable staff - Speakeasy knows what they're doing and they excel at it.

Speakeasy has truly cultivated an outstanding community in the area with their frequent events and accessibility to the public. Not only do they produce award winning beer that is made with unbelievable amounts of love - but they are all about listening to their customers and are truly excited to hear what their customers have to say.

Support your local brewery. Support Speakeasy.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description:
Speakeasy is the rare brewery that executes a variety of styles very well.  I've started to become jaded with double IPAs (they have a tendency to be too hot and unbalanced), but the Double Daddy Imperial IPA blew me away with its delectable combo of tropical fruit and pine resin.  The Bourbon Barrel Scarface Imperial Stout also excels:  it seamlessly meshes the chocolate, coffee, and booziness.  Other highlights:  the Belgian dark ale, Payback porter, and imperial stout.

I love the vibe of the brewery as well:  a very friendly staff and chic lounge area.  I only wish that Speakeasy had a second location in Santa Barbara (where I'm from)!
author: Jason Z.

description:
Props to Mike D. for showing me the way to tha Speakeasy. I heard about the Happy Hour at Speakeasy but it was Mike Deezy that actual brought a fan here. 

We came here for a little pre-gaming before hitting AT&T. Hell it's on the way, right. Dressed in my Giants gear, I naturally ordered the Fear the Beard Ale (or whatever it's called). Kinda Orangy, like I like it. 

Outside they have food vendors. Taquitos, Burritos, tacos and on the otherside, Good Foods Catering with the super good BBQ. I believe the two best match ups for beer tasting.

Great crowd and that day they had a live band, too bad we missed the show - but we had priorities MAN - GO GIANTS!!!!
author: Rebekah T.

description:
Great hidden treasure in SF. My boyfriend is a big fan of their beers so we decided to check this place out since it's relatively close by my neighborhood. Speakeasy is borderline ghetto Third street, but it's a great place to go if you're looking for great beer in a spacious bar with sexy 1920s prohibition vibe. They have the bar with two mini rooms if you have a large group to go with. They also allow you to wander to the back where all the magic happens. This place has become my favorite place to go because it's honestly really difficult to get great beer in SF for cheap. 

Pros:
Plenty of parking
Large selection of their beers available on tap
Sexy am-Beyoncé 
$3 Happy hour (1-6pm

Cons:
Not open for late night
author: Mable N.

description:
If you're a fan of Speakeasy's Big Daddy IPA or Prohibition Ale, you need to head towards Bayview despite the trek and make it to the Speakeasy brewery. 

A true SF brewery, you'll easily find the afore mentioned brews in most bars in the city but it truly makes a difference to come straight to the source and be taken on a tour of the facility and given some inside scoop into the brewing process. The tour is super casual and our guide was very knowledgeable and hospitable. Folks here in general are really nice and more than willing to answer your questions. Pair that with pints of their harder to find/seasonal brews like the Vendetta IPA, I was one very happy camper. 

They have a new bar as featured on Thrillist as one of "The Eight Greatest Craft Beer Openings Since Last Summer" and I can't wait to be back for more.
author: Jon L.

description:
I was able to get a tour around here and wow, the craft of making a beer is great. Will be coming back since the beer was fantastic and the staff were so kind!

*update. Try that Philz beer collab. I went to heaven as soon as I took a sip of that!
author: Sweets N.

description:
This place is awesome! You can just stop reading the review now (or go on for more details).

The location is a little odd, but it is a brewery and you've got to be located in a place where you can operate your business. That said, it does have parking and the tap room is pretty cool. A little dark, a little mysterious, and plenty of taps serving up the Speakeasy offerings.

The beers are great. They have a nice selection of several different beer varieties, but in my view the strengths are the IPAs (the big West Coast thing these days) and the dark beers. My personal favorite was the chocolate milk stout, but all were excellent.

Best of all, we were there in the middle of the day, and happy hour is $1 off all beers from 1-5pm Tue-Fri, which makes it an exceptional deal.

Maybe next time I go I'll take home some 22 oz bottles or a growler, because the beers are seriously good and most of the groceries around only have a small selection.

Definitely check it out.
author: Brent W.

description: John the rep is down in so cal at burger house sharing his knowledge of his awesome craft beer. The flight sample was so awesome and he knows his stuff.  Double daddy rocks. A great craft beer now on my list.
author: Kathy H.

description:
Beers and vibe totally rock. This place is one of those Jewels that the typical tours I will never find, and I've gotta say that's ok by me.
Their beers are uniformly excellent, and span a broad variety. They don't serve food, but at least during midday the Rodrigues Brothers taco truck was just down the street and the burrito was wonderful.
Behind the bar, Mollie was queen. She was engaging, helpful, friendly, and handled a busy bar with aplomb and still found time to answer beer geek questions.
I was able to try only 8 of their beers this time, but I will be back and I will look up their beers in my local stores!
author: Arizona J.

description: This brewery has been on my to go places for ages! I traveled all the way from Orange County just so I could experience this place. I've been a fan of this brewery and enjoyed all of their beers. SPEAKEASY brewery, you were the highlight of my San Fran trip. I wish you had food though!
author: Monse A.

description: They make some of the only beers I can drink.. Turns out I like dark coffee-like beers -- the payback porter and the scarface are good for that. They do tours and and have a sweet bar on the other side, speakeasy-style.
author: Vivian H.

description: Amazing beers. Had their seasonal pumpkin pie porter and it was one of the best pumpkin beers I have ever had. My husband hates pumpkin beers, but he liked this one so much that he kept steeling my pour and drinking from it. I call my husband a beer snob because he usually finds something wrong with a beer, but not here. After a glass each and sharing two flights to sample all that was on tap, he was speechless. While it is a little "off the beaten path" it's completely worth it. We are heading back tomorrow to pick up some beers to go.
author: Rene R.

description:
My wife and I just had a blast here, this was our favorite brewery on our San Francisco trip.

What made it so good?

Pros:
The staff was excellent, we interacted mostly with Kevin and John. They were both very engaging, patient with our questions/orders, and made sure our experience was superb.
The beer was top notch. We ended up walking out with one of their unique growlers as they had a saison that was unreal, I gave it a 5/5 on untappd. it was the first saison I really enjoyed to that level.
It was less busy than the other breweries and tap houses we went to. So we had no problem finding comfortable seats.

Cons:
Maybe we drank too much and then bought too much goodies. :) Not necessarily a con.
Maybe some out of towners will think it is further away than other breweries - (this might be true - but just take a uber - it will be worth it)
author: Nate B.

description: Having a pretty awesome time. Love the variety of beers and what have you. Wish there was food. Happy is at 1pm to 5pm
author: Selina K.

description: Speakeasy Ales is a great place to be with friends. The ales and craft beers are outstanding. They have tables inside and outside also. The prices are a bit high.
author: Jeffery K.

description: I came to visit a friend in SF a few weeks ago and she suggested we come check this place out, as I was looking for local breweries to visit while there. I was far from disappoint from the 1920's style ambiance, to their great beer! Ricky was the one to serve us and was more then helpful and informative in helping me pick the right one for me! I too work at a brewery, so it's really nice to receive that impeccable service you'd expect from any other in the industry. I absolutely will be back again on my next visit!
author: Breanna V.

description: It's a brewpub in a not-very-trendy, downright industrial part of town that serves beer, some snacks, and growlers to go.  The bartenders are nice people, willing to answer questions about the beers they have in their medicine cabinet as well as what they have on tap.  Decor is in line with the company's name.  Some of the beer in the medicine cabinet can be pricy, but you can get out of there for under 10 if all you are interested in is a pint.  And don't forget to say hi to Brew Kitty when she decides to come out of the office to say hello--she loves the 4505 Meats chicharrones.  This is good place for a group to meet and hang out.  They offer brewery tours on the weekends, and it's pretty nifty to see how they brew the beer and move the ingredients around.
author: Herb L.

description:
BIG. FAN.

This place...this place!!  Where do I begin.  So as an east bay resident, I've wanted to check out Speakeasy for sometime now...but for one reason or another (ahem, bart fire, cough) I have been halted in the process to make it there.  I was poking around on the speakeasy website (which, btw, is goodbeer.com .  AWESOME!), and saw that they were hosting their upcoming 16th annual blockparty.  Sat Sep7, 1-6pm, $35 unlimited pours...well that there is a no-brainer, but add in live music and food trucks? Sold.

We found out you could buy tickets at the door (good to know next year) and that they were in no way going to sell out of GA tickets (VIP admission however had sold out.)  So anyway, we parked in the shade nearby a little after 1pm and saw that there was a line to get in.  Hubby was none too pleased, he hates a line.  so we got in line and it didn't take too long to get in, so no big deal.  One dude checking IDs and distributing bracelets, it was all pretty smooth.  Also, if you do bring kids, they will charge a Designated Driver type price/fee, which is kinda bogus but I guess keeps the adults partying and kiddies at home :)

So we get our tickets scanned, a second wrist band (weird), and our 6oz tasting glass.  They were super cute glasses with the 16th annual block party logo plastered on it.  We would be on the hunt for leftovers later!  Got in and went straight for a beer tent...they had 3 total, some with different offerings than its counterparts.  New beers I hadn't tried in the past were... Buthertown Blake Ale (Black IPA):, Witness (witbier), a new SFBG Common (lager), Double Daddy Imperial IPA, Big Daddy Wet Hopped (IPA), and a Tellulah Extra Pale Ale.  The old standby's that were yummy were their Payback Porter, Prohibition Amber, and Big Daddy IPA.  No stout, and their Vendetta Red is coming out mid-Oct, yay! 

What a glorious day, 5 hours of drinking enjoyment (last call was shouted around 5:40pm).  The only complaint would maybe be the length of the beer lines...thankfully they moved super quick, yay.  The tap room was awesome as they had it setup for live music that penetrated (yeaaah) the entire brewery/parking lot.  Lines for the porta potty as well, but also moved quick.  It was a warm September afternoon in SF, but at hunter's point it was breezy and pockets of shade to help get you through the hot afternoon.  But by 5:30pm it rapidly cooled off and it was so wonderful.  They also had some really cool schwag/merch to purchase so that was cool.  Water for everyone to keep hydrate is always appreciated.  4 food truck/tents to choose from, but nothing really stood out.

Speakeasy, you'll see me next year...but hopefully much sooner and more often now!
author: Sara W.

description: The place is not huge, but it's quite nice - very atmospheric, with wooden things around and nice decor. Good selection of beers, very nice staff, a perfect place to spend a couple of hours on a lazy afternoon.
author: Pawel K.

description:
Whoa! A review could not wait! To put it simple and clean, this place is awesome! The staff is really friendly and accommodating, and the bartenders are on point!

And the beer is... Just whoa! Need I say more? Okay, so far we've had the the witness, the talulah, and the scarface ( 2
Pints and 2 four oz samples). The verdict: amazing! I've never tried so many beers and be so satisfied at the same time :).

Overall: Speakeasy? Yes, it is, especially when there are a selection of good beers to try at 3-5 dollar per pint! This one is a no brainer, definitely coming back here when I'm in San Francisco.
author: Jan Jeric M.

description:
Great place to drink and chill with friends or meet people just hanging out at the bar. 
Very cool room and we took a brewery tour with Veronica who was super sweet and informative. 
A definite hot spot to chill anytime and enjoy excellent local brews!
author: Mark N.

description:
After having called the Taproom throughout the day on a Sunday and not getting anyone to pick up I imagined they must just be busy so I took off from work early in order to make it before the 9:30 PM Last Call, as it is advertised on the Speakeasy website. To my chagrin, when I got there and asked for a beer the first thing the lady behind the counter said was "how did you get in?"! 
Apparently they had only had a few customers that day and decided to close early in spite of the website hours... why they didn't pick up the phone if they weren't busy beats me... what really gets me though is that at 9:30 PM there were still 3 employees there just killing time, while I as a customer couldn't even get one beer! 
On my way home I then managed to pick up a bottle of Speakeasy's Imperial Stout from Whole Foods and found it to just be ok... was looking forward to trying the barrel-aged version but I don't think I will bother going back to the brewery.
author: Larry D.

description:
Who wouldn't want to ride on a revamped old school bus with other beer lovers and visits a bunch of SF beer rooms?! People I don't want to associate with! Kidding, I love everyone! This was the first stop on the Yelp Field Trip Beer tour I went on with Justin C. and other really fun folks!

I have been to Speakeasy before for another Yelp event a year or so ago and this tour was a little different. We were put into the small walled off area inside the brew house, it was very cramped, and given small pours of some of their beers. I feel that this closeness brought our beer tour group a little closer, literally. We were also given an impromptu expansion into the actual brew house and tasted some more beers. We later went into the bar area and had more beer. This place has great brews and the staff are really welcoming.

We left to hit up the next place but not before we bought a great beer with a waxed top, I don't know what it was but it looked pretty!

They have a pretty good sized parking lot and there is still great street parking!

You have to stop by yourself and experience Speakeasy!
author: Constance D.

description: I was lucky enough to have a weekday off in the city on a day when Lyft was 50% off, so I took advantage of the situation and visited an out-of-the-way place. Speakeasy Brewery is in an industrial park in SF between The Dogpatch and Hunter's Point and they have a tap room set up like a prohibition-era speakeasy (of course!). It's pretty small, but cozy with comfy couches and lots of corners to hang out in. They don't sell any food other than some snacks and there weren't any food trucks nearby, so don't come hungry; however, they were re-upping with their pickle and mustard supplier while I was there and they were cool, so snacks are definitely worth trying. They have 12 taps with all of their regular beers plus a few special brews, so if you're a fan of Speakeasy beers, it's definitely worth a visit.
author: Rob B.

description:
$4 pints!

As if I need to say anything more...

Great vibe, comfortable seating, patrons low on the obnoxious scale. 

Not exactly a convenient location, but that will hopefully keep the riff raff away. 

Parking isn't a problem with the large lot and street parking.
author: J. M.

description:
This is one of my favorite California breweries. They have a nice selection of ipas and a quality barrel program. Last time I came here I had the big daddy ipa on cask and came back with a bourbon barrel aged stout The Syndicate.

Nice atmosphere and friendly staff, its worth a stop for a few pints.
author: Taylor G.

description: I love this place.  Speakeasy has a great selection and their barrel aged beers are to die for.  Keep it up guys and looking forward to the next time you "open up the cellar."
author: Shane F.

description:
Went here over the weekend for their little fundraiser event "prohibition party".  It was very makeshift but we had tons of fun anyways.   

We did manage to wander into the bar.  Love the speakeasy look and feel of the decor but without the frills  and pretentiousness of reservations, passwords, and secret entrances  of the bars in the city.  Just a great place to hang out and try some of their beers on tap.
author: Bianca P.

description: Went on a brewery tour and spent time at the bar area with a small group of friends. The brewery tour was fun and very informative. The guide gave a lot of insight on the process and was helpful to all of the questions asked. As a fan of dark beers, every dark beer they had was high quality. Definitely would come back.
author: Raymond D.

description: Great brewery in SF! I had been buying their beers in stores for a while, and finally made it out to the source. It's a small place with friendly bartenders and solid beer. No food or liquor. One time I came and the bartenders gave us a tour of the brewery because it was a slow night. Really enjoy Speakeasy and look forward to going back.
author: Ryan Y.

description:
Staff was friendly, and drinks were great. The beer was by far my favorite of all of the breweries/pubs that I have gone to while in San Francisco. Here are a list of my favorites in order for reference: Speakeasy Ales & Lagers, 21st Amendment, ThirstyBear, and Public House. (I also went to Southern Pacific while here. It was not my cup of tea. The beer there was mediocre at best, and the atmosphere was awful. Most of the staff was not friendly or attentive to concerns. I wouldn't recommend anyone to go there. Hence, that is why I didn't even put it in my list.)  

But back to Speakeasy, go there during the week from 1-5 p.m. They have great happy hour prices-$3 pints and $4 for belgium pour. Sidenote, BigDaddy IPA is by far my favorite. One detraction from the place is that it is in an industrial like district. You will not just be walking by for most people. You will need to make plans to go, but doing so would be an intelligent choice.

P.S. Tell the bartender Kevin hello.
author: Trey H.

description:
Came for the SF beer week event.

Excellent beer, nice new tap room.

I was a little disappointed having shown up at 8:30pm, paid $30 at the door, and they turned the beer off at 9:15pm. I misunderstood it to be until 10pm, wish I bought beer tickets instead =(
author: Doug R.

description: Really neat tap room. All their beers are well balanced. I really enjoy their Pilsner and Lager. The bartenders were super friendly and let me try anything before buying it. Definitely worth checking out. Decent amount of parking in the area as well.
author: Kyle F.

description:
Whoa!
I just got on line to say how much I have enjoyed the PROHIBITION ALE. My first choice in dark beer. Not bitter, real smooth. I really did not know there was actually a place in SF to go and drink one right at their brewery. So thumbs up for this beer and I will visit the Brewery very soon and rate it. Love out of the way places.
Chris
author: Chris D.

description:
We came here for their Barrel Aged Scarface release for SF Beer Week. The bar was already packed when we got there so we grabbed seats in the smaller rooms. The newly renovated tap room was dimly-lit and its speakeasy decor gave it a wonderful, intimate atmosphere. The bartenders were friendly and the service was excellent.

I got a flight of the following beers:
Double Daddy- One tasty double IPA
The Black Hand- This milk stout was a little thicker and I could definitely make out a slight creaminess.
Payback Smoked- Drinking this smoked porter reminded me of eating smoked bacon. You can't dislike that.
Scarface(current)- This imperial stout had great aroma and flavor but not my beer of choice. The other beers in the flight were simple more interesting.
Scarface 2011- Could not taste the difference between the two years
Barrel Aged Scarface- Aged for 18 months in bourbon barrels. I enjoyed this one the most because the sweet taste of bourbon lingered on my tongue between sips.
Unfortunately, they were out of the Green Death malt liquor.

I followed the flight with a pint of double daddy. Its hard to resist the hoppiness and spice!

The prices are very reasonable. For example, the flight of 6 beers was $9. I just wish they offered some sort of food, because that would have allowed me to stay and drink more.
author: Alfred L.

description: Love this local brewery because it just down the street from my house. All the bartenders, brewer, and security are awesome and friendly to talk to. I come here on weekly basis because it's that awesome!
author: Tam J.

description: Came to have a tour and have some good catered bbq. Called the day before to reschedule and confirmed moving it back by two hours. Showed up and tour guide was extremely rude and said we were not on the list. Did not make any attempt to apologize or reschedule us to another time. Said another group was late and they moved them back but the guy we talked to on the phone didn't tell her he moved us. Bbq was good but service was terrible.
author: Damon N.

description: honestly a neighborhood highlight - it's inexpensive, parking isn't a problem, nice staff, and a divey but tasteful, clean atmosphere.
