I'm pretty obsessed with their chocolate milk stout, wasn't a fan of their pop gun (pilsner?)... either way, 3 beers racked me up $14 so there is absolutely nothing I'd complain about. Well, maybe the red lobster commercials that kept showing up on their TV - cheddar bay biscuits, anyone?
author: Ryan L.

description: Great, old-timey dark lit ambiance. Plenty of seating. Terrific beers. Cornhole outside. Dogs allowed outside on the patio. My favorite is the Blackhand, a chocolate milk stout. I'll be here again.
author: Daniel N.

description: Yeah, I know it's a brewery, but I wish they had anything alcoholic that's not beer. The person who was with me isn't a beer drinker. Well, but that didn't really matter, because service was so good. And I'm not a person who likes outgoing waiters and bartenders. I prefer to keep it discrete. This was a whole other thing, though. Molly was probably the naturally nicest bartender I've ever met. She helped us through the beer problem, too. Beers are good, of course. I like the looks of the place too. On the small side and cozy. Lots of wood going on. Or some imitation, I can't tell.
author: Lucas C.

description: I love this place. The beers/variety they have is so much more than at the store and everything is tasty! Really cool layout, live music on the weekends and even a poke guy! You buy a tub of poke and they pair it with beer and it is delicious! wish I was closer to this place!
author: Zara S.

description:
Gayle and I paid a visit to the Speakeasy as part of our Yelp Field Trip. I like their beers, especially the Big Daddy IPA and the Scarface Imperial Stout.

Gayle later posted an outside picture of me on Facebook with the following comment: "Naturally, we are the oldest people here. Waaaay oldest!" Not entirely, although maybe my relative impatience with beer lines might be age related. Plus Yelp crowds are always fun, and I enjoy the conversations, whether I've met folks previously or not. It's also enjoyable to have Gayle with me, as my writings often put her in an "famous" light for those who read my reviews. 

The Speakeasy facilities are a little funky out in this light industrial part of town. And all during my visit, I kept putting on my professional hat and wondering how these guys do when the Fire Marshall or Cal-OSHA show up. It's definitely a labour of love here, the quality of the product speaks for itself, and after Gayle made me zip my compliance comments, I decided that their safety commitment was just fine.

The first 8 ounces (or so) was free, and maybe in hindsight we should have gone to the pay line and cut the suspense short. The color ticket system for the Brewery Tour was also a little confusing, although we enjoyed the table where the various hops and grains were on tactile display and tasting. Also available were related goods for sale, and a food stand with some decent looking BBQ. Speakeasy was also smart to provide some Security as a couple hundred young adults and beer don't always mix together smoothly. We found everyone working the event to be friendly and helpful.

All in All, it was a pleasant event and well worth the drive over from the East Bay. Many thanks to Jessica and Ruggy for making this event possible and to Speakeasy for opening their doors and their kegs for many of us to sample and enjoy.
author: Eric B.

description: God I love this place. Returned a few weeks ago for the 2nd time (it's far out from SF), on a Sunday night. It wasn't too busy, and the bartender (German woman) spoke to us for the whole hour. It was really laid back and we enjoyed sampling all the beers during the chat. Would come back here any day
author: Kerry G.

description:
Went here last Saturday for a nice afternoon. Loved the vibe of the bar- dark, a couple rooms with tables for larger groups, fun decor. There was a solid group there that day, but not so crazy that you couldn't sit or easily get a beer. The 4 of us each got a beer and we headed outside to enjoy the weather and grab a barrel table. After 15 minutes it was time for our tour. We were with a guy that was doing just his 2nd tour ever. He was a fun, laid back guy. Sometimes he wasn't super confident about what he was telling us, but he'll get better with each tour he gives! It was neat to see their facility and we were able to grab a couple empty cans to take with us. After that, we had 2 tastings (a stout and an amber) and we were done! We grabbed another beer and a picnic table and stayed a while. They had a DJ out there and some corn hole sets. Overall, a nice way to spend a couple hours on a Saturday!

OH, they also had a BBQ place there selling chicken, pork & ribs. It smelled SO amazing, but by the time we were done with our tour at about 3:00, they were sold out and packing up :( Guess it was just as good as it smelled.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
Awesome beer, lovely bartenders!

I've been to the tap room at this brewery a few times and I have never been disappointed! My favorite beer has to be the Black Hand (the chocolaty one), I never fail to get myself a few glasses of it every time I go. The ambiance is relaxed, casual, and a little mysterious ;) The bartenders are also really nice people, that make you feel welcome the minute you walk in. They also go above and beyond when the occasion arises. The last time I went, about 5 days ago, it was my boyfriend's birthday and chance has it that 2 other customers were also celebrating a birthday too. The bartenders were warm and even gifting us 4 oz tasters so that we could toast and sing "happy birthday" to the 3 birthday folk. I thought it was really nice gesture that most places wouldn't have done and it really made the occasion special for the boyfriend.

Thank you!
author: Sandra H.

description: Pretty good. A smaller inside venue, that is dark, mysterious, and rather nostalgic. Speak easy beers are a big aggressive for my palette, but having them fresh lifted the experience. The servers here were friendly, and they had great music playing.
author: Peter T.

description: Loved everything about this place. It is very creatively decorated inside, although the outside looks a little sketchy. The bartender was so friendly and very informative on the selection of beers they had. There's a small lounge area towards the back of the bar and a small store right at the entrance. I would definitly recommend this place to beer lovers.
author: Kitty D.

description:
Chill prohibition atmosphere, composed primarily of local, return guests. I've had their beers from Total Wine & had to check out their brewery while I was in San Francisco. I was not disappointed, great selection; from their prohibition ale, big daddy ipa, & payback porter to their newer Massacre (which is soo smooth) that I fell in love with it. 
          The smell of hops in the air that hits you every now & then is like a siren's song. That will be one of my fondest memories of this brewery. Relatively inexpensive will be another reason to return. Personable bartender Clay made my experience super chill!
author: Jeffrey B.

description:
Some friends and I went to Speakeasy Brewery on a Saturday night. We arrived around 4pm and stayed until about 830pm-9pm. The area is safe as it's located in an industrial part of HP. I appreciated that they had their own parking lot, which is convenient. It's pretty easy to locate and the outside is clean and the landscaping is well taken care of.

General Info: The bar itself does not sell food, but there was a food vendor outside. People are welcome to bring in the food and eat inside. The décor matches the image of the beer-dark, mysterious, yet comfortable. They have a couple nice nooks and benches to be more intimate. The ambiance is casual and the crowd is laid back. The restrooms were clean the entire night and the bartenders used clean towels. The bar itself was also very clean, which is important to me personally. 

The customer service: The bartenders were super friendly! They enjoy their job and engage in conversations with customers. They do not get stuck in one conversation and ignore other customers completely. They were very attentive-clearing glasses, checking in, and describing the beer and brewery. They were knowledgeable, but not arrogant. 

Last but not least: THE BEER. My group and I tried every single one on tap through flights. They were all delicious and aromatic! I am not a beer guru of any form, but I know what I like. My favorite has to be the Prohibition Ale. It was soft, yet flavorful. I also enjoyed their Tallulah Seasonal brew. Their beer is delicious and they have something everyone can enjoy. 
In closing: If you like supporting San Francisco, enjoy craft beer, and are looking for a laid back ambiance-this is a great choice!
author: Natali R.

description: My favorite brewery! Love the people and location. The employees are awesome. Great selection of beer and decent prices.
author: Jeanine D.

description: Nice tavern-feel to the taproom. Dark lighting. Very small, therefor fairly loud given it's a popular place. The beer is good. Random location that is a little off the beaten path, but worth the drive!
author: Kyle R.

description: Nice place to hang out with friends for drinks. This place is strictly a bar and they don't serve any food. They have a variety of beers on tap, so I would suggest ordering a flight to try a little bit of everything. If you enjoy a game of jenga, they have a small game room where you can play with jumbo jenga  blocks which is pretty fun.
author: Frances V.

description: Great beers, great atmosphere. It's even got its own parking lot, so you don't have to worry about finding parking in the city.
author: John S.

description:
You have to love living in a place like San Francisco where we're surrounded by some of the best craft beers you'll taste anywhere in the entire country. Possibly outside of Portland and San Diego, there are more delectable suds flowing from our little slice of California than just about any other part of the world. And while most of the local beers you'll find on tap are coming from places in the Russian River and other surrounding areas, Speakeasy is one of **8 breweries doing the deed right here in our own backyard, and they might be one of the best of the bunch to boot. 

**The others are Magnolia, Beach Chalet, Gordon Biersch, Anchor Steam, Social Kitchen & Brewery, 21st Amendment, and Thirsty Bear... just in case you're curious. 

Tell me a brewery with more refreshing libations, and I'll treat you to a swift kick in the rear to get you out of my face. Their libations taste like 1,000 John Tesh's have arrived on my palate to serenade my soul. Some of the standouts include their black IPA, their signature Prohibition ale, and a whole host of delicious special releases that always prove to be winners.

At the actual brewery itself, they just started doing a series of Friday night parties where you can head down to Lo-Do (new microhood you're hearing here first... Lower Dogpatch) and see the facility first hand! It's a hell of a good time that should be enjoyed as often as possible.
author: Ruggy J.

description: The warehouse has great events, great  beer, and the prices are on point.  There are so many awesome beers to sample and I love that these awesome beers are SF brewed. The brewery tour is a fun date idea and worth the hike out to HP Bayview area.
author: Chelsey G.

description: Hands down coolest tap room in San Fran. Me and a friend made a full day of visiting the popular breweries in the city and both agreed Speakeasy was our favorite. The beer they make is amazing, didn't try one I didn't like. Highly recommend the Butchertown Black!
author: Will W.

description:
i LOVE what they've done with this place!

they have a lot more choices of beer now since when i first started coming here couple years ago. 

i really enjoy variety so i love how they have 4oz tasters. i had to get one of EACH :D
author: Katherine C.

description:
LOVE this place!

Came here for HH with my coworkers and I did not leave disappointed! I am already a fan of their beers, but the venue is amazing. They have couple large rooms for big groups, seating at the bar and several chairs/tables for your use. The way they decorated inside is awesome.

They also have a cat roaming around, which I was a fan of :)

Upstairs looked like a bunch of offices, which I think is kind of neat!
author: Heather R.

description:
Hubby is a beer aficionado so we made a point of dropping in for their 15th birthday bash yesterday.

Rude awakening - he enjoys a cold one but not standing up and not being able to slam it as these beers are very stout.

We tried three different ones and ended up pouring  a lot of it into the garbage.

He does better with the right setting. So maybe he's not a beer aficionado after all.
author: Shirley N.

description: We went here and did the brewery tour. It was only six people on a Saturday afternoon. The tour was very informative and laid back. Took about 25 minutes to go through it and then you can buy some beers on tap and sir around at the bar. My husband really enjoyed it. It is easy to find and park.
author: Raven J.

description:
Cute place to chill and grab a couple of cheap beers before heading off for the night! 

Do I see myself becoming a regular and hanging out often? Definitely not.
Do I see myself coming back to take the tour of the brewery? Definitely a possibility!

Located in the HP, I was initially really nervous about the neighborhood. Once I've arrived though, all those thoughts went away. The brewery has it's own parking lot with ample parking close by!

Once inside, the whole place is basically a giant warehouse with plenty of beer, food and people. What they lack, however, are seating areas. So I highly recommend you to be ghetto and bring your own seating!

While I am not too big on beer, even I couldn't pass up the 2 beers AND a souvenir glass for $10! They also have free popcorn and a little tamale stand.

I'll most likely be back one day for more beer and to check out the tour! Yay!
author: Tiffany U.

description: Really cool spot! Beers are strong and delicious.  No food at the bar though.  Really wanted some fries!!
author: Shauna H.

description: Stopped by for the first time yesterday and it has a great vibe and of course great beers. There was an outside vendor selling BBQ so that was great too. Only wish they had more food selections.
author: Glenn G.

description:
Speakeasy has tasty beers, and their tap room is warm and inviting. I've been there a few times over the past year and always had a great time. The bartenders are nice, and the "Medicine Cabinet" is always stocked. You can get bombers and growlers - the growlers are especially convenient for those limited edition beers on tap that you can't otherwise get. Though they don't have food on-site, they have a food truck schedule on their beer menu, for those of us who like to snack when we drink. However, if you're there during the week, be sure to grab a burrito or something in the Mission on your way out there! Otherwise, you'll be SOL.

I'm not giving it 5 stars because of its location and my latest experience there. It's in Bayview, in a spot that feels like it's in the middle of nowhere. Getting there by bike is somewhat of a chore, and I can't even imagine having to take public transit there. For those of you with cars, it's no big deal. 

I went this past week with a friend for a couple of drinks. Normally, the bartenders call "last call" well before they close, but they didn't this time around. I couldn't recall if they closed at 8 or 9 on weeknights, and since my friend was able to order us each a beer at 7:45, I assumed they closed at 9. I was wrong. At exactly 8 p.m on the nose, the bartender started making comments about us leaving and them closing. I was forced to basically chug an almost-full beer (with help from my friend) and scoot out the door before the bartender literally pulled the stools out from under us. I understand that they don't want to hang around any longer than they have to, but it would have been nice to get a heads up before we were ushered out the door.
author: Tracy J.

description:
Folkin' Fridays! Brews and Bands, love it!
Casual folks hanging around drinking beer while listening to bands jam!
great prices on beer there, and to go if you have growlers.
food- ehhh eat before coming here or bring something to eat.  The taco stand they have set up is great and all, but not filling.
Music- changes all the time.  I'm not a fan of playing indoor since the sound is bouncing off everything and it is LOUD.

Amazing and super chill. Recommended on for a friday!
author: Bobby L.

description:
Off the beaten path, the tasting room looks and feels like, well, a speakeasy. 
  The beer is outstanding. Big fan of the Big Daddy, Double Daddy, and Prohibition Ale. They sell awesome looking growlers, bombers, six packs, and pint glasses.
  Don't think they serve food, but remember this is a tasting room, not a bar. The atmosphere is laid back, not a tv to be found. Keep the cell phone tucked away and soak in the great beer, atmosphere, and company.
author: Matt M.

description:
I came upon this place when a friend and I decided to walk to the bay (from Bernal Heights :0). The walk was industrial and pretty deserted, and then we came upon this in the middle of an area that was basically industrial parks. I wasn't sure if we were allowed to go in from the outside, it's pretty nondescript and I thought it might just be a wholesale outpost or something...

My friend and I came in and were transported to another world. The've got it decorated like an old speakeasy, complete with old fashioned looking light bulbs and a little button on the wall that you're supposed to press if the speakeasy gets busted :)

Their flagship ales (three choices) are $3 until 6, which is pretty darn cheap, and their beers are tasty. They've got cute sweatshirts and tshirts for sale in the front. 

It's a nice ambience, and was definitely a welcome respite on our walk. I forgot it was daytime while we were there, and was pretty much blinded when I walked out (there are no windows and the lighting int here is quite dim).
author: Meryl S.

description: We biked here during SF beer week. I love Big Daddy and was excited to try more Speakeasy beers. However, its was soo crowded, hot and loud. I could barely get to the bar to order a drink. There was standing room only (or sitting on the stairs). They had food trucks outside, but you couldn't bring beers out there, so it felt discombobulated. Speakeasy, I still love your beer and will order it elsewhere, but the tasting room needs some improvement.
author: Leah B.

description: First stop on a brew crawl.  Kinda out of the way, in an empty neighborhood, large free parking lot.  It was the only place we had to uber it, but not too bad.  Cool looking place, several nooks and crannies to hang out and relax for a bit.  They only sell beer, which was pronounced very good.  Friendly bartender.
author: Lola K P.

description:
Great on a Sunday. BBQ truck parked in the lot out front and $3 beer specials. 

If you can, grab the private room off the main bar and park it for the afternoon and sip beer and eat food truck BBQ.
author: Lee H.

description:
Came for the open Yelp event. There's plenty of parking nearby, probably because it's located in the less than desirable Hunters Point neighborhood. Tried their Double Daddy IPA, the Prohibition Amber, and the Big Daddy IPA. I especially enjoyed the Amber, which I thought would make a nice beer to drink after a long day of work, when you've kicked up your heels. 

They don't have food available for purchase on site, but there are usually a few food trucks where you can get some grub. Bring a coat; this is basically a giant warehouse, and while they have a few heaters, it's definitely chilly inside!

The brewers here obviously love what they do, and it especially came through on the tour. Support local beer!
author: Leslie H.

description:
This place rocks! It's a brewery not really set up for entertaining but they do and they do it well!

You buy chips at the door and go in and buy beer from the keg master. Last Friday they had this double down strong beer that was rich tasting and delicious, their prohibition, a blonde, a stoudt, and a belgian style. All delicious. People bring their kids - so there were about 10 cute little kids running around playing - give's it a picnic family vibe that's surprisingly cool. 

Since they're only open Friday evenings - everyone is appreciative that they open it up and it's easy to talk to anyone.

Very Cool.
author: Rew C.

description: I absolutely love this place. When you charge $4 per pint in San Francisco then I'll definitely be back. Not only is the price good; their beer is absolutely amazing. You can never go wrong with their Big Daddy IPA. Their porter was also a good one. Personally, I have to be in the mood for a porter but it was definitely not a mistake to try it. I also decided to try their Wet Hopped Big Daddy; that was definitely a tasty beverage as well. It was nice patronizing this place talking to people who enjoy good beer.
author: Michael B.

description: Now this is a friendly brewery, I mean it this place rocks. The friendly bartenders go above and beyond to size you into the right brew :) I just love this place, Ambiance, amazing. Brew's on tap, the best...even the seasonal bottles are well informed by the bartender. I just want to stay in this dark brewery and enjoy my pint. San Francisco is engrossed with pretentious bars, fortunately this gem is not like the others. Spend some time at Speakeasy and enjoy the boozes and company because, nothing tops this place. Cheers.
author: Sneakrs 1.

description:
Came here for the Speakeasy Brewery's Saturday Beer Blowout. The event said it would start at 4pm, so got there at 3:30 and there were already a few people wondering if they could go in. At 3:50, hoped in the line and the doors opened at 4:10. It was nice from 11am to 6pm that day and by 6:30pm the rains started coming hard.

Inside they had 2 areas serving beer. The first is the original place for their tasting. The second was a makeshift bar that had for the event. By 5pm the 1st bar was completely packed and people had to go to the 2nd to avoid the 30 minute wait. 

 The event itself was a good idea, just the amount people and the amount of space available was bad. There was only one food truck that bother to come out, so the lines were really long. I am sure, Saturday's event was a fire hazard. 

Wouldn't go again unless they put a cap on the amount of people..
author: M C.

description:
The Bay Area is craft beer heaven. It s a beer blessing to live in San Diego, craft beer capital of the world, but the Bay Area comes a close second.
The taste room is open on Fridays, you pay for these tokens and then you go exchange those for beer! Beer is cheap, plenty, delicious. I usually stick to the Double Daddy and Big Daddy IPAs but they have everything for every taste from Pale Ales to Stouts and Porters to Lagers and Brown Ales. 

In other words, friday afternoon beer heaven.
author: Claudia A.

description:
I went here one Saturday & had a very interesting experience. There was only 1 bartender working - her co-worker had some car issues & wasn't able to make it to work til 3 hours later. I forget the bartender's name, but she was cool. She had to run the bar by herself & it was getting busy. 

Interesting thing happened...a homeless guy ended up coming into the bar & started bugging a lot of the customers. The bartender tried to be professional & tried talking to the guy to make him leave, but he wasn't really listening to her. Around this time there was about 20+ people in the bar & the bar tours where coming in. She was holding down the bar on her own & did her best to chill & stay cool.

My bf & I ended up chillin at the bar for awhile & helped her deal with the homeless guy. We ended up having to call the cops on the guy to get him out, but the customers seemed to be understanding to her situation (working the bar alone) so most people we pretty chill. 

This location is not anywhere near busy areas, so I can assume on the weekdays it's pretty chill. 

Beer is good & if you want the samplers, they're only about $1.50.
author: Michelle F.

description: The staff was great. Fun and happy personalities, knowledgeable about the different beers. Beer was delicious! We tried Big Daddy, Pop Gun, California Love & Double Daddy. We  had a great Thirsty Thursday here!
author: Jayme C.

description: Reminder: Consuming copious amounts of beer without food available leads to early drunkenness.
author: Dora C.

description: The Tap Room here is great! I've tried several of their beers and each was excellent. $4 beers and most are well above the average 5-6%. If you like dark beers, the Scarface was a standout and 9.5%! They have a large area in the back that is open on Fridays as well and have someone from La Laguna selling food which is really nice.
author: Adam K.

description:
Pretty stoked about this place due to it's Awesome reputation. It was a hidden gem among industrial buildings. The area was quite large and very welcoming. When you order your beer be aware that they use a "Beer chip" system in which you purchase chip tokens in one window then take it over to the bartender. Kind of strange, I assume it's to relieve the chaos, but it seemed like just an extra person to tip. The beers were pretty good (And only $3!), the reviews about the Double Daddy were correct as it was very good. But The witness smelt like ham. In fact it tasted like ham? Weird..

There were a bunch of free stickers and pins with their logo on it, which was cool. But their shirts didn't have any pictures of their logo with the eyes. Bummer.

Evidently the brewery is only open to the public on Friday nights, which seems to follow the trend of a speakeasy. The placed was packed, their were even kids running around! I mean tiny babies and toddlers. I guess there's no complaint for that, as it was a friendly environment, just kind of makes you nervous as it's a dangerous area. Very friendly customers and approachable staff. 

Oh and they have a brewery cat!! Awesome cat!!! Big black cat with a huge belly that every one thought was pregnant. Apparently she's just an excellent mouse hunter.
 
I did hear a rumor that they will be opening a tapping room which will allow for more business hours. I'm excited for that!. Oh and be aware that they only do one tour on Friday so get there early!!
author: Kayla D.

description: This place is off the beaten path but definitely worth it. The staff is awesome, especially Molly and Jeff. The beers are amazing - a must try is the Blind tiger while it lasts. They're down to their last keg
author: Ravi A.

description:
Best kept secret in the Bay View!!

Walk in, get tokens, go up to the bar and grab a beer.  As someone who doesn't drink beer often, I really liked it!

TIP: Bring a chair! You are literally drinking inside their brewery and surrounded by barrels.

My Giant and I were a lil' scared to be going to the area at night, so we did not know what to expect for the first time.  But never fear, they had bouncers bigger than my Giant on staff that night.

The lady selling Mexican food at a little table inside was so nice...and the food was tasty according to my Giant. :)

Free parking, no cover, CASUAL (I was a lil' over dressed...) and smoker friendly.  iPod is blasting some good tunes through a lil' beatbox.  

Seriously such a great place!
author: Stacey D.

description: We made the trek to Speakeasy not knowing what to expect, but being premium beer lovers, we figured it was worth a try. We were not disappointed! We love the vibe at Speakeasy, the warm wood interior, chairs to lounge and, of course, great beer! We had the Vendetta IPA, Big Daddy IPA and, my personal favorite, Double Daddy IPA. I highly recommend a trip to Speakeasy next time you want a great experience and fantastic beer!
author: Cheri K.

description:
SF's nudists should embrace Big Daddy as their official beer. (-:
Why? Because it's awesome and because the crowd @ Friday's brew tours are so chill, I doubt they'd notice the occasional nekkid nebbish.

Of course, you can wait months to get on the Anchor Steam wait list.  Or...you can haul over to Bayview at the end of every week for Speakeasy's Firkin Friday from 4-9 PM.  A $10 spot gets you two pints and a souvenir glass.  Additional pints are $3...just be careful about doubling down on the Double Daddy IPA!

Was afraid the neighborhood was going to be sketchy, but it was totally fine. We even walked the pup around beforehand and she had a nice nap in the car while we toured.

There's a taco vendor who sets up inside...snacks were muy bueno!  If the onsite snacks aren't enough, check out SF Guardian's recent foodie recommendations for Dogpatch/Bayview...they look pretty solid.
author: rhonda s.

description:
I'm not much of a barfly, when i do go for a drink i like cozy spaces and decibels that allow me to hear my companions. Used to be speakeasy was one large crowded room with few scattered chairs and catered food. Well, times have changed! A warm and inviting pub-like space was carved out of the building and features a bar with stools as well as two cozy, upholstered alcoves and tables and couches to spare! Nice!! Much improved space and the always great beer has even more teriffic varieties to choose from. Thank you workshop founder kelly for designing this clever and welcoming brewery/living room.
Now i'm glad to visit and enjoy the vibe unlike pre-remodel.
See for yourself, speakeasy is better than ever!
author: Kelly K.

description: Went for my birthday and had sooo much fun! I went on a Friday, just in time for happy hour, so there were a fair amount of people there, but it wasn't crazy crowded. Seating sucks, but they let people chill in the back, which is spacious. They offer some finger foods in the back, but not much, so if you're vegan or vegetarian I recommend stuffing your face before going. Great vibe and a friendly staff, I will def go back.
author: Vanessa B.

description: Get a tour on Sat. And Bourbon cask beer on tap :)
author: Oleksandr Y.

description:
I've been twice now. 

Once for the Friday evening party and the second was for the anniversary. Both times the vibe set right with me; good music, great food stands/trucks and how can you go wrong with 2 beers and souvenir glass for $9.00! 

i had a blast
author: Jade W.

description:
Pretty cool speakeasy/bar. It's pretty far out from central SF which has a ton of things to offer so I don't know if I'd make the trip out here again but I enjoyed it while I was there. Pretty small variety of beers but they quality is definitely there. Each person has their own preferences on beer so i won't say anything except that I liked them. 

If I'm ever in the area i'd stop by but it isn't so amazing that i'd go out of my way.
author: William L.

description: I never imagined a speakeasy brewery....but this is it! Dark, intimate, cool decor with leather couches, and lots of seating, all in a funky industrial area. I was impressed with the tasting and even more so at the price! $6 for a flight tasting of four IPA's. The bar was packed for a Tuesday happy hour. I can't wait to come back. There is no food so don't come hungry.
author: Marie D.

description: The new tap room is worth the trek to Bayview just to see. Darkly lit with the neon "shhh" sign and wooden panelling, friendly bartenders... I'd hang here everyday if I could! Payback smoked porter and a number of other "rare" speakeasy brews yum! Be sure to try their SF beer week beer...it tastes like malt liquor. Brings back college memories.
author: Nikki M.

description:
Racist! Racist! Racist!  My niece wanted to try several of their beers. My sister and her began to drink there beers. When the real nice black security guard told us in the future please do not bring children. We were not there to get wasted. According to there website it is a tasting room not a bar. My niece addressed this to Mike the bartender. She researched the website to confirm this. I did called to get the Managers name Mike said Alexa
        My impression Mexicans are not welcome to there? (were not white washed dude! were Mexican)!!! 
Ultimately they asked us to leave!! We explained that we are from Los Angeles.
        Mike was very adamant that we were not welcome there!! I felt Mexicans should not visit this place if you to be on alert!! Mike gave my niece a courtesy glass for asking us to leave the glass was dirty when she unwrapped it.
        As we were gathering our things to leave Mike sent the security guard to get our glassware quickly as if we were going to steal them! Never again. 1+ hour drive from hour hotel to get there. what a waste 
Por favor no vas a visitar este lugar son Racistas!!!.
author: Alicia G.

description:
A friend of mine has been here quite a few times. He was the one who suggested a longtime-coming reunion with he, I, and a friend of ours. We showed up at about 3pm and didn't leave until around 8 that night.

The Tap Room is, in terms of size, the sort of bar one would expect to see in the front or side of a nice restaurant. It's not very spacious, but I imagine you aren't expected to stay long (as opposed to me and my friends). The seats are all comfortable, even the stools. The only concern is showing up at the right time to find a seat, otherwise you'll be standing.

If you have the time, you just might find yourself having pints of the entire Speakeasy collection and picking up a few collectibles to take home. Though I don't go to Bayview often, I'm glad my friend showed me the pub in this place. We're already planning when we can go again.
author: Charles L.

description:
DRINKS:
Speakeasy beers are all very ... tasty. On the menu were many that were higher than average alcohol by volume 


SERVICE:
bartenders were very attentive


ATMOSPHERE;
Very cute, speakeasy feel, with the speakeasy door, and old looking bar. Apparently there's BBQ trucks on Sunday and occasional live music. The live music makes it really awesome. At least when we went for the Google City Expert event, it was swanky prohibition kind of band. The only thing is this is so far away from downtown SF, it's in the middle of BayView/Hunter's Point.. Felt like I was back in the suburbs of South Bay. Not very SF feel. Maybe if they opened up a tap room in the middle of downtown/SOMA, that would be perfect. :D
author: Angela L.

description: On a whim, set forth from smoggy LA to SanFo & chanced upon this brewery. with a rustic decor and a round the corner friendly feel, Loved the ambiance & people, its a place to go & enjoy brilliant ales.
author: PiaCabs C.

description: Awesome place! This is what I'm expecting at a brewery. Great atmosphere and delicious beer!
author: Alex P.

description: Best bar I have been to in a long time. Everyone is very friendly. Shout out to all the guys that let join their game of Bones. Great times guys. Can't wait to come back
author: Alan R.

description: Seriously Speakeasy, ENOUGH WITH THE KIDS RUNNING AROUND! I would give you five stars because I love your beer. But the screaming kids running around has to stop! Definitely other breweries to go to close by that don't have this problem. By the way is it illegal for anyone under 21 to be in the tap room area?
author: Scotty M.

description:
I've been meaning to go here for quite a while, but I'm always working during the time that their 'taproom' is open so the second I had a free Friday evening I jumped on the opportunity to go here.

Tip: Don't get off the bus two stops early. Or drive. Driving's probably your best bet because in most cases it is going to be a very long and very packed bus ride.

I was quite happy once I made it in the brewery. The system inside is you go up to the counter to purchase poker chips ($3 a chip) and you go to the guys pouring tasty brews and trade a chip for a pint. The guy at the counter hated my guts for some reason (was it because I wanted to buy a hoodie?), but the dudes pouring were pretty awesome. 

I'll need to come here again with some friends. There is a huge amount of space to hang around.
author: Kyle K.

description: Once you get over Bayview, this is an intimate tasting room with nice, attentive bartenders and tasty beers!
author: Kellen F.

description:
Visited them yesterday for their SF Beer Week open house.  For years we have wanted to visit, but were always hesitant by the location. It was no problem and they have lots of parking close by. 

The place was packed but the staff was on it and organized. Seriously props to the staff for controlling that many people.  Beer is bought through tokens for $3. I would suggest bringing cash because the line can get long otherwise. Not sure how many beers they normally have pouring on Friday nights, but there were a lot of seasonals and classics, about 10. Double Daddy, Payback, and White Lightning were wonderful. Wide range of people enjoying local beer and they even had root beer for those under 21. They had beer and live music inside their warehouse and an outside area for relaxing/smoking and food trucks.  Oh...the food trucks were good.

Been brewing since 1997...they are doing something right and it shows.
author: Erin S.

description:
Came here for an free art event. It was awesome. Their always having some type of free event for the public, and it always brings out a good crowd. I like the beer here and it's close to home so it's a win win for me. 

I will be returning every time they have something going on, and so should you.
author: Louis C.

description:
Speakeasy Ales and Lagers has been around for a long time, but their speakeasy themed tasting room has not. Put in a little over a year ago, it is the best speakeasy themed spot I've seen. Great attention to detail. Great ambiance. 
With $3 happy hour beers, and $6 tasting flights, it is the most affordable place in the city to get fresh local craft beer. And beer is best fresh. 
They also have free parking in their lot...I don't always want to drive, but it is nice to know it is there if you just need to stop in and get a growler to go.
author: Melinda E.

description:
Its tough to find a place that combines good beer, friendly people and outstanding prices. Somehow, this warehouse out on Hunters point has managed to do all three. 

I love that I can not only indulge in fresh Speakeasy beer for three dollars a pour, but occasionally in live music and fresh food, ranging from burritos to barbeque. I love the clientele, many of whom are remarkably friendly, especially considering that you get a true cross-section of people, ranging from hipsters to recent transplants from the wilds of Texas. I love the back patio: great place to enjoy the sunshine that seems constant in this part of the city, smoke a cigar and enjoy a delightful beer. 

One of the only downsides is the location: not only is it the brewery in a bad part of town, but its also a schlep from most parts of the city, and without a car can be quite difficult to get to.

I look forward to the Fridays when I have the time to make the pilgrimage to Speakeasy.
author: Casey U.

description:
I came for the SF FunCheap's Speakeasy Brewery's Saturday Beer Blowout event (https://www.facebook.com/events/415884448428671/).  It was kind of a glorified beer tasting... except with insane lines.  They had giant Jenga and a large Connect Four game.  And giant checkers.  Sadly, giant games do not equal giant fun.  Except for maybe the Jenga.

I should've known better than to go to an event for a beer I wouldn't drink if I was at a bar.  

Three stars for effort though.
author: Erika C.

description:
Love the $2 beers every last Friday of the month. Nice that they feature a new or exclusive beer during that time too. I recently had their Scarface Stout--very coffee-like and smooth. Double Daddy is pretty solid too. 

I like the atmosphere and environment of the brewery. People that are there are always chill, including the staff. Last time I was here, the bartender filled up my pint cup with their 12oz-only pours instead of giving me a 12oz cup--dope!

Seems to be a family-friendly environment considering the youngins running around or strapped to a parent's chest. 

Come out here if you want to enjoy cheap, delicious beer in a friendly, relaxed spot!
author: Norwin E.

description:
Great place to have some beer and enjoy the company you bring with you.  They have a very cozy environment inside that really brings out the "Speakeasy" feel.  I enjoyed the beers and look forward to them doing tours.  The price is extremely reasonable for their beers especially when you compare to the City.

I highly suggest checking them out.
author: Lance P.

description:
Shhhh, Speakeasy:

White Lightning ~ (6/10)
Big Daddy IPA ~ (8/10) 
Prohibition Amber Ale ~ (7/10)
Double Daddy Imperial IPA (9/10)

Great beers all around. I wish they had wider distribution!
author: Gary R.

description:
I'd never heard of Speakeasy before going to happy hour on Friday. Not that I'm a brewery encyclopedia, or a fount of malt & hops knowledge, but it's a little surprising to find out that apparently I've been missing out on really good beer for quite some time.

Speakeasy's in the Bay View, right next to a toxic treatment plant I believe, but do not let either fact deter you. Their happy hour is such an incredible secret! Every Friday, 4-9, $3 tokens to get a 12 or 16 oz pour (depending on ABV) of one of the approximately 8 selections they have on tap. There's food available, but why waste valuable belly space on food when you can drink delicious beer? I tried the Butchertown Black and the Prohibition Ale, both excellent and quite strong. I also sampled the red ale (I forget the name but it was excellent) and the Betrayal (free!) upon the urging of the President/CEO, Forest.

But the beer's not the only great thing. Everyone in attendance - company employees and the varied crowd - was extremely nice, very open, and fun to talk to. There was a real sense of community and pride in the operation. If you want to impress your friends and make them envious of how in the loop you are, take them to the Speakeasy happy hour! One of the best events I've ever had the pleasure of attending in the Bay.
author: Corinna K.

description:
For awhile I was intimidated.

I'd heard you could only come on Friday, the servers surly and newbies beware.  After finally checking a map and noticing that it wasn't completely out of reach, I decided to catch a cab out here and experience it first hand.

Speakeasy built it's reputation here in San Francisco with their deliciously hoppy ales including Untouchable, Godfather, Double Daddy and the awesome White Lightning.  Visiting the brewery it was nice to see that I could enjoy the old favorites as well as some new exclusives.  The Butchertown Black is a limited black ale that drinks like a hoppy stout.  The Sutro Stout was addicting and flavorful.  The Vendetta, an IPA brewed with orange, was also incredibly enjoyable.  

You know you're getting quality beer when you come here so let's look at the other facets.  The vibe is chill and laid back.  People from professionals to families to people just looking to start the weekend right are here enjoying suds.  At $3 a beer for most pours (12-16oz), this is one of the best happy hours you could probably find in SF.  There's some light munchies available and a proper bathroom.  The size of the space is just right, not seeming empty yet with enough room to spread out.

As most lament, the ride to and from here can be dubious.  Thankfully the T-Line is only a few blocks away and it you're feeling stranded or impatient, you can always duck into a few of the bars on 3rd Street before deciding on your trek home.  Overall worth the hike for a quality experience.
author: Steven R.

description: You gotta check this place out it is awesome! Highly recommend for happy hour.
author: Erin G.

description: Kicked off Beer Week at Speakeasy. A bluegrass band played on Friday evening. They had a hollowed out mobile home/bus that they transformed into a food truck which served an amazing beef brisket soaked in one of their brews. Their fries weren't too bad either! A bit salty but that only makes you thirsty for more beer :) A Speakeasy mug and 2 additional chips for a couple more drinks for $10 inside the brewery. The bartenders were fast and until they shouted last call the crowd was tightly knit near the beers on tap!
author: Samantha L.

description: I'm not the biggest fan of their beers, but the brewery is a great punk rock place to hang out. Haven't been back since they opened their tap room, but prior, Friday afternoons, punk bands, putting green, smoking on the "patio", perfect place with little crowds. Can't wait to check out the full taproom.
author: Lupolo K.

description:
Hubby and I are regulars here on Fridays. This is one of the best breweries we are lucky to have in San Francisco. 

There's always something for everyone, I love their porter and their stout. But they also do a great IPA. There's free popcorn! and each pint is like $3!! Yes it's a bit out of the way but trust me, it's worth it. 
They sell you tokens at the door for each pint and if you don't use them up that night you can save them for next time! 

We like to go get a pair of Ike's sandwiches and head over to this place and just scarf down one of the best sandwiches known to man along with a few pints of the best beer in the bay! =)
author: Ireri L.

description: Speakeasy is one of the overlooked breweries in SF that lies in the shadows of Anchor Brewery. Sure, it's not in a great, convenient neighborhood but at least you don't have to book reservations like at Anchor to enjoy the beer and the facilities. You are, able to grab drinks up at the bar, in one of those cozy, private booths up front or in the back area. At times, there will be local food vendors serving food or bbq during the summer. The beers are great, the venue is spacious, and the patrons are true beer enthusiasts.
author: E E.

description: In response to my previous review: great customer service. Problem resolved, thank you Speakeasy. In the process got to visit the taproom, awesome little space to grab a beer. Weird location though but the beer is worth it.
author: Christina J.

description:
Fantastic place to come to get the weekend started. I can usually only find 2 of their beers in stores (Big Daddy and Prohibition) so come here if you want to try all the great brews they have!

Hours: Friday and Saturday from 4-9pm

Price: 2 beers for $10 and a pint glass with their logo on it to keep (great deal)

Beer: Great beer for everyone. Lighter beer (White Lightning), IPA (Big Daddy), Amber Ale (Prohibition), Imperial IPA (Double Daddy) and the Payback Porter on tap last time I was there, amongst others.

Scene: Complete mixed crowd here. Everyone is welcome and everyone should feel comfortable. People start rolling in when it opens but it really picks up closer to 5:30. Music starts up around 6 or 7pm. There is a small outdoor area just off the side of the warehouse.

Food: Not a place to come and eat but every time I have been a local Mexican restaurant has come in and set up to sell some pretty good and well priced food. Taquitos for $1 each. Tamales and mini burritos for $3 each. Not a full dinner but something to soak up some suds.

Other: Grumblers, T-shirts and other schwag for sale. Also, Chicharrones from 4505 Meats for sale - awesome!
author: Frank J.

description:
Experienced my first Friday Happy Hour tasting on 12-30-11 and WOW, what good times shared by all. I went with my wife and 8 year old daughter. This particular night the tastings from 12oz on there specialty beers to 16oz on there house brands was only $2 Usually it is $3 which is still a great deal!.

Yes, you are in a warehouse but they crank up the ceiling heaters. The crowd is very easy going and no attitude. Maybe it changes? later in the evening after a few more beers but we got there at 4:00pm and left around 6:30pm I think it stays open till 11:00pm? so maybe then the beer takes effect on the crowd?

It can be boring for little people. They only serve water for under 21 (It is a brewery after all) I did not expect Sarsaparilla. There is Mexican vendor food served which is a good deal and free pretzels this night.

I was drinking the Godfather IPA and the Scare face Stout. This is a beer that you eat more then quaff down. The best compliment is I will be back!
author: Rawley D.

description:
First time being at this location and it was great. $3 beer and great people just hanging out and having some fun.

Only thing i don't like about the location is that it's located not to far from Hunter Point area.
author: M M.

description:
Awesome staff, great beer.

So. I've recently learned that I sound totally ignorant when I say, "I'm not a beer person." Apparently, I'm told, there's a beer for everyone. And CRAFT brew is the way to go. 

Unconvinced, I STILL decided that a beer tasting networking event sounds like much more fun (and far less intimidating) to most people than wine tasting. So I went ahead and booked a private party at the Speakeasy Brewery.... on short notice.

Did I say short notice? RIDICULOUSLY short notice. Like 2 days. AND. I needed the event on a day they were doing production and NOT normally open. 

The ROCKSTARS at Speakeasy pulled it together and seriously knocked it out of the park. GREAT beer, VERY cool staff. (Like you kinda want to hang out and be part of their little indi brew/"in a band" friend group.)  AND the caterer they suggested has become my new go-to. They were fast, flexible and totally reasonable. They knew my budget and came in under. Seriously. Who does that?

The one and only ding is that yes, the location is a bit of a hike... and a bit hood. I think we scared people off by saying that it was near HP/Bayview. From now on we're going with SOSOMA. (South of SOMA.... Deep south.) Our attendance FOR SURE suffered because of the location. And while they DO have ample parking, with those kick ass beers... who wants to drive? 

100% will use these guys again. I'll just rent a party bus to get people there and back. And I'd hire a band... Make a night out of it.

And humbly, I admit, I found a beer I kinda liked. White Lightning. 

I LOVED working with Speakeasy!!
author: Robyn H.

description:
This spot is for the grown...don't need to be sexy kind of crowd.  Just cool and wanting to unwind on a Friday.  Cheap beer as far as the price but doesn't taste cheap at all.   2 of my very good friends and myself hung out here for a few hours just catching up.  

We're in a warehouse surrounded by the brewing machinery, free popcorn, a few chairs, tamale vendor and folks wanting to have a good time.  This place is so chill and relaxing people bring their kids here.  

yes...for all you peepz with kids..your kids are welcome at this spot.  

I'd definitely come back here again.
author: Blue S.

description:
Their beer is quite good.  That's for sure, and they have a lot of varieties here they don't distribute to stores.  

But the atmosphere is a carved out area of empty cement slab inside their warehouse, a lot of their specialty beers aren't actually that amazing, and it just doesn't feel like a destination type place.  Maybe if they sold food, or did tours, or had more chairs, it'd get a fourth star.

They also have an odd payment system -- you buy tokens at the front door, which you use to buy beer inside; I prefer a standard pay as you go type system, but I see why this is more efficient for them.
author: Zachary R.

description: A fun place to go to, great atmosphere, local area to drop by after work, and some good people to talk to. They are getting a pretty good selection of beers so there is always something for someone in case their choice is very particular.
author: Billy C.

description:
One of the best breweries in California.  Great beer at great prices.

My wife and I attended the event they had for SF Beer Week on February 17th.  It was our first time there and the experience was great.  It was a great atmosphere and the beer and tacos were delicious.

I left with a case of the Double Daddy IPA and I can't wait to go back.

If you're in San Francisco on a Friday evening or Saturday evening, I recommend Speakeasy for good priced, good quality beers.
author: Santiago U.

description:
Things I love about Speakeasy: 
- It's a great stop on the way to the city.
- The neighborhood doesn't seem too bad, despite the Hunters Point location.
- You don't have to buy the glass, like you do at Devil's Canyon.  $3/beer w/o the glass! (I don't need anymore random beer glasses!)
- Unsuspecting location and very casual. 
- Indoor, real bathrooms. 
- White Lightening beer. 
- 4505 Chicharones are sold here sometimes!
- It's every week, not just one a month! 

My biggest gripe:
- There aren't any signs with names and descriptions about the beer. There are some special taps that the guys pouring the beer could be better about talking about. They just expect you to know what you want.
author: Rachelle T.

description: Cool place, great beer. The only reason I'm not giving it a five star review is because its resident feline sits on the bar. Maybe it's just me but I'm not too keen on setting my drink where a cat regularly puts its anus. Also was a little "ugh" when I saw it put its face in one of the water pitchers meant for the customers.
author: N J.

description:
The time to go here is Friday afternoon when they have food and everyone is hanging out trying beers and socializing.  For $5 you get a pint glass (souvenir) filled with whatever beer you want and refills are only $3.  

They give a tour which is quick, fun and informative, then it's beer time.  

Yes there my be a few kids running around but its not a medical marijuana dispensary, its a brewery.
author: Sloppy P.

description:
This is how cool all microbrews should be. What a fun experience! Headed up to SF for dinner, I happened to find Speakeasy on Yelp and quickly directed the car that way. Parking was ample. People were nice; one great thing about SF (as opposed to the south bay) is that there's all kinds of people at every event. The beer was new, refreshing and relatively cheap.

So $10 for a Speakeasy pint glass and two beers? That's pretty good. I tried the White Lightning and Prohibition first. Both were good. Tried some Big Daddy (hoppier than I like, but I'm not an IPA person) and whatever the porter is called, and both had distinct, refreshing flavors. The bartenders were helpful and very patient.

Did I mention the free popcorn? How about the random stand selling mexican snacks? It's just a cool, laid back atmosphere.

My friend actually said the stop at this place made his night; no matter what happened next, he would have gone home happy!
author: Akash K.

description: Wow what a treasure for west coast beer fans. With a killer, purposely DL setting and location, speakeasy's tap room delivers fresh, hop-oriented beers for a great value. Cool-assed speakeasy gear as well as bottles and growlers to take with you also available. Beer specials til six everyday.
author: Michael O.

description: I almost want drinking to be illegal again after visiting this taproom. Old-school feel with modern amenities and of course, delicious beer. The bar is one option, but there are also three rooms off the main for more privacy. Altogether well-done.
author: Jeff H.

description:
Such a good spot.  Really 4.5 stars.

 I went with a group of friends for a Frickin' Friday, and I felt like I was surrounded by a bunch of hearty regulars who were happy to see new faces.  All the beers are solid, and it seemed like such a good deal for beer of that quality.  

My favorite part: the cute mom/daughter selling taquitos and burritos (for a whopping $1 a taquito or $3 a tamale or something).  To advertise them, this guy would periodically shout out like Will Ferrell's Harry Carey "HEY!!!  HEY!!!  We've got taquitos here!!  I KNOW you're Hungry!  HEY!!  Come over and eat!!"

And even though my ears felt blown off, it invariably worked, and a few people would buy them.  I eventually was one of those people.

Anyway, good vibes, great deal for quality beer.  Only downsides - it's far away from me, it's only on Fridays, and it's FREEZING.  Bring a jacket, scarf, whatever.  They have to keep the doors open so 'nuff said.
author: Annie F.

description: Speakeasy put out for SF Beer fest. Can't go wrong with the strong Scarface Imperial Stout or the aptly named Massacre (Black Wheat) and at over 9% you better pace yourself. Those $3 beer tokens are so well spent. Though it was a little crowded, it was mainly the typical eclectic crowd- everyone from parents with super young ones, to grandpas and everyone in between. The taco stand outside was fairly tasty as well, decent prices to match the beer. Though it was cold out (as SF fog usually goes) they kept the mood light with entertaining bands and a friendly crowd.
author: Naomi K.

description: I can't believe I ever used the excuse of "it's too far away." It was literally a 15-20 min flat bike ride from the mission to beer wonderland. Beers are fantastic. Their new tap room is gorgeous as well. Speakeasy is definitely now on my weekend go-to list
author: Whitney W.

description:
I wasn't quite sure what I was expecting but I was definitely not expecting to drink beer in a warehouse. And I definitely was not expecting to have fun drinking beer in a warehouse. For $10 I got two pints and a souvenir glass. The souvenir glass is awesome because it has the mysterious speakeasy eyes... ooOOoo ....

The beer itself took some getting used to because I'm not a big fan of hoppy beers. Hence, I ended up drinking only four ounces of each of my 2 beers and making my friends drinking the rest of the beer =)

And I definitely loved getting a free Hansen's Cherry Vanilla Soda. I love cherry vanilla soda.
author: Kay A.

description:
Double Daddy's are my poison of choice here, but after 4 cups I'll start seeing double! This place kicks my ass every time I come here, but it's a fun way to spend a Friday night with some friends! If you go hard here, don't plan anything crazy after, or you'll wake up not remembering what you did the night before!

It's pretty obscure and random to find, I honestly did not know what to expect when I first came here, but they make it work!

You buy chips at the door and you can trade in the chips inside for beers. The free popcorn is a nice touch too!
author: Tien P.

description:
Pros: Great Friday happy hour! Excellent beer!

Cons: Kind of out of the way, so have a sober driver or take the bus -  as taxi's will not come out here to pick you up (I learned the hard way).
author: Brooke S.

description:
I talked with Melinda (I accidentally called her Melissa in our emails and looking back I was so embarrassed) while planning a birthday event for 28 individuals.

She was extremely friendly and let me know about the brewery bar hours/rates. She also said that she would let security know our large party would be arriving on 7/13, and this allowed entering to be much easier.

I think that GoodBeer offers a unique, unmatched spin on the bar/brewery experience. It's a great place to take any sort of group - big or small. Also, the beers are only 3 dollars on Fridays from 4-9 pm in the brewery. That's such an awesome deal - especially for quality beer.

If you are an event planner, or about to become one, I would definitely consider stopping at Goodbeer at some point in your party's trip. It's an easy way to bring people together without having to walk through the hassles that reservations, bouncers, etc. that other bars and clubs frequently present to planners.
author: Natalie S.

description: Great Environment to sip on some beer. I ordered their beer sampler, which is pretty cool because you get try a bit of each of their beers. They have happy hour here. I think it is around $3 for a pint. Worth it, definitely coming back here to enjoy the good vibes again.
author: Dilys Y.

description:
Even though located in the edgy and shabby industrial neighborhood, this brewery/bar is unpretentious and as good as it gets. 

Free parking, no cover, hidden, not yet experienced Asian Invasion (nice blend), large smoking patio, unique blend of beer and a very friendly staff.

A nice change from the usual chic HH places in fidi.
author: Catalina C.

description:
The legend of the infamous Speakeasy Brewery Friday Happy Hour from 4-8pm had been on my brain for a while.  This event promised to be the stuff legends were made of.  

Images of cherubim fountains spewing streams of beer and joyous folk diving headfirst into frothy pools of ale and lager billowed through my mind.  I fancied myself sipping a pint whilst comfortably lounging on a fluffy cloud of wort.  

Perhaps it was the delicious pint of Hunters Point Porter that I drank the night before at Broken Record still coursing through my veins, but on this particular Friday the draw of Speakeasy was unavoidable.  My future existence in the world was contingent upon it.  When I woke up in the morning, I knew that today would be the day myth would become reality.

After kidnapping workaholic Lauren Y., tying her up with duct tape, and shoving her into the hatchback of my PT Cruiser (with the help of Brooke G.), I started driving furiously toward Hunter's Point.  Successfully dodging a number of lovely Bayview gentlemen driving "cars" with busted out windows, licking their lips and honking at us all the way down Evans, we pulled up to the Speakeasy warehouse around 5:00pm.  Greeted by the creepy Speakeasy eyes and the glorious stench of beer and cardboard wafting through the air, we walked through the door and saw beer boxes and kegs as far as the eye could see.  

                                        :::queue angelic hymn::: 

The signature happy hour special is 3 pints + 1 pint glass for $10.  Sweet deal!  If you're a lightweight, you don't have to drink all of the pints that same day.  The bartender administers casino chips that can be redeemed for your choice of brew anytime.  Also, for you lightweights, they have a popcorn machine so you can put a little something in your stomach if you opt for the Double Daddy (double hops, double malt, 9.5% ABV) and feel yourself getting a little tipsy. (*cough*Lauren Y.*cough*)

The atmosphere was so refreshingly casual - you're free to roam around the warehouse, chill at the bar, go outside, whatever - and everyone was hanging out, enjoying some GREAT beers, and chatting.

Besides the really phenomenal brews (I was VERY impressed by the complex, strong flavors, high alcohol content, and well-balanced taste), the highlight of the whole visit was something that could only happen to four 20-something girls drinking pints of porter.  Amen to that! Some guys also frequenting the happy hour invited us for a ride on their Burning Man, chick magnet, 4-seater bike/surrey/contraption/definitely-not-street-legal (even if we were sober) "vehicle," complete with chain-link cup holders.  While dodging buses, laughing hysterically, and pedaling as fast as my legs could handle with my two best friends and a beer close at hand, I thought to myself "How could my life get any better than this?"

Big thanks to the stellar brewmasters at Speakeasy.  I'd also like to thank the geeky LARPer engineer who built the "contraption," his hippie Seth Rogan look-a-like friend, and the creepy old guy with the double-pierced ears.
author: Erin L.

description:
In honor of the new Ken Burns documentary "Prohibition", I went in search of the secret establishment in the Bayview that served up those sweet ales and lagers that needed code-word clearance during those years in the 1920s & 30s. 

Alright, that's a boldface lie. I didn't know about the Ken Burns documentary. I just wanted people to think I watch PBS. I was really just looking for a place to hang out on a Friday with some good beer. Luckily, Friday nights at Speakeasy Brewery fits that description. On Friday afternoons starting at 4pm until 9pm, Speakeasy Ales & Lagers opens its doors to the public to enjoy their beers. We didn't get there early enough for the tour, but the warehouse looks pretty small, so I imagine that the tour is fairly short. 

So we showed up around 7pm and the place was packed! Parking in the lot was full, but there's plenty of street parking around there. Look for their trademark neon eyes staring down at you, daring you to order a Bud Light. Don't be confused. You'll be drinking in the warehouse. Nothing fancy. You walk in and buy some tokens for the beer. $3/token for a 12-16oz pour, or for $10, you get a Speakeasy pint glass and 2 tokens. I personally loved the pint glasses. They also have plenty of branded clothes to take home as a souvenir. Trade in the tokens to try out some of their brews like Prohibition Ale or Big Daddy IPA. They also had a few of their lesser known beers like the Double Daddy and White Lightning. I would have liked to have tried some of their specialty brews, though.  In terms of food pairings, they have a popcorn machine popping out batches of buttery popcorn and a small stand selling Mexican food (flautas and stuff?). Popcorn's free (woot!), Mexican food is not.

The crowd is surprisingly mixed. More kids than I expected, but you got your after-work 9-5ers, saggy pants Giants fans, skinny jean hipsters, and possibly local SF City College kids. All milling about on the brewery floor. A few tables and chairs are spread out, but most people are standing. I would say it's a cool place to hang out with a group of friends who are into the Speakeasy beers, maybe not so much for meeting that special someone. 

Password not necessary to gain entry into this Speakeasy, but you'll need an ID.
author: Saunders C.

description:
I dropped by Speakeasy last Saturday for the 10th Anniversary party and had a fantastic afternoon. $5 for a souvenir glass and 2 fantastic, delicious, frosty beer?  Yes, please!
Awesome party, I'll definitely be back to check out one of the Friday happy hours.
author: phil h.

description: I'm happy to support the local little guys. And their small tour/operation here is definitely worth a visit and a return visit to the tap room as well. Walked away with a growler full of SF Lager. Looking forward to coming back in the future.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
I came here for the yelp event recently (my second time at the brewery) and I have nothing but positives to say about this place. 

1) The atmosphere is chill, it's all about hanging out with your friends and having a few great beers. The staff are all really friendly, and the Head Brew Master is really chill, and has a sense of humor abotu questions on the tour even if they are silly (ex: my friend asked to be hired). 

2) The beer is excellent, they have lots of varitey, and the staff make good recommendations about when you might like. At the yelp event I was able to try a flight of three tasters, and I liked all of them (although the White Lightning is my favorite). Also, full beers are only $3 a piece, and you can't beat that. 

3) The food trucks are great, especially the bbq. I had the pork belly sandwich, and it was awesome, I almost went back for seconds. Basically Speakeasy knows what it does well (beer) and find other people who do food well (the trucks) to help them make a great event. 

I love this place, and I plan on going back for one of the Saturday night openings.
author: Leslie I.

description:
This is not your typical place brewpub.  That's because it's not a brewpub.  They don't make food.  They only serve their beer and invite a food truck or two... at least, that's what they did for the one time I was there.  Their 2011 Halloween Party.

My wife and I loved it.  It's super industrial inside and out.  They roll out a portable bar / kegerater and start pouring their beer.

As a sidenote, I'm not a huge fan of their beers... although I love their Double Daddy which unfortunately was only served from bottles that night.

The atmosphere and overall coolness still forces me to give them 5 stars despite their good (not great) beer.
author: Chris P.

description:
Fridays from 4-9. Limited hours I know, but a good time to drink your week away. Like everyone else, you get 2 drinks and a glass for $10, or for your next round 3 drinks for $10. 

I came for the beer and left with the Who's Your Daddy? tee shirt.
author: Drake F.

description:
I love getting my beer straight from the source! I'm a fan of their porter, though I'd like to, for once, be early enough for the coffee porter.

Yeah, it's way out there, but that is part of the charm. 

You can either buy a souvenir glass + 2 tokens for $10 or $3/beer. 

They start shuffling you towards the doors around 9pm. That's not too early though as the beer would have already kicked your ass x 3 by then.
author: Tinna H.

description: AWESOME place to hang out with great beers at reasonable prices and very knowledgeable staff. It's cozy and unpretentious. Too bad the brewery tours don't start until July. I will definitely be back for it.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
If these guys served beer out of the depths of hell, they'd still deserve five stars because, yes, their beer is THAT good. I've been drinking Speakeasy and visiting the brewery since before they had a liquor license to sell beer for on-site consumption, and could only GIVE beer away. Those were the rough days that guys like me had to go through so that guys like you can enjoy 3 beers and a pint glass for $10!

The brewery is definitely chill. There's no froo froo tasting room setup, just a warehouse with lots of beer making "stuff", lots of cases of beer, lots of kegs, and a long counter top with several taps pouring all the Speakeasy favorites you see at the store/bars, plus lots of "specialty" brews that you'll most likely never see anywhere but here. Its beer heaven.

If you can get over to the brewery I can't imagine a better way to spend a nice Friday afternoon after a long week of work. If you CAN'T then at least go pick up a six pack of Big Daddy - you won't be sorry!
author: Jeff S.

description: These folks make my favorite beer. Big daddy and the coffee porter are my tops for the last year or so.
author: John O.

description:
Simply the best off beat hidden secret in the Bay!! 

Location: 
Speakeasy is in the cuts of the ghetto of the city. You know your there when you see those giant eyes staring you down. Plenty of free parking. Was a Little leery of the sprinklers all around the torn down building next store's we enter a sigh of relief. Really cool big venue Would love it a little more localized but it was a great time, Super friendly staff. They are only open one day a week "Happy Hour Friday's" from I believe 4pm to 9:00pm. Now on Saturday too!!!! 

Beer: LOVE the beer here, yummy stuff go for the Big Daddy which is about 6.5% alcohol and the Double Daddy which about 9.5% alcohol. 

They only take tokens, as you walk in you see a big sign for the prices three dollars a token which given you one pint or you can do the 2 tokens and a souvenirs glass for $10.00. which gives you a $5.00 cool speakeasy glass and two tokens which gives you two pints. 


People: a wide variety of people. I saw a good amount of hipsters and family which was surprising and some suits mixed in with the casuals 

Service: Bartenders are suppose to be serious to go with the theme but they are really friendly. The bouncer Jesse and Ronnie are awesome. 

Food: They have popcorn and A Mexican food booth to help you wash down the cold tasty beverage. 

. 
Pros: Cheap delicious beer which a great staff, big location free parking, no lines. They do a free tour in the beginning of the open happy hour, hour's 

Con's: a boom-box as music, need an option for water, I know I said it but I want a safe DD drive. Oh and it's cold so you need a jacket.
author: Raquel O.

description:
Came here for my friend Randubious' birthday. Its located in the more Industrial part of the ghets, so if you're afraid of location, this place is pretty damn isolated/safe.

The inside is pretty awesome... its a warehouse stocked with boxes of packaged beer, and what I am assuming are 6-10k or larger fermentors... it pretty much looks like what I do at work, but done in a warehouse atmosphere.

They have a chip system for getting beers.... i believe its 1 chip for a pint, 4 chips to fill the growler. We opted for the 10 dollar deal which got us a souvenier glass and 2 tokens... that is a freaking DEAL right there! Apparently, this happens on Friday's every so often.

The staff is very friendly, and one of the keg masters helped me pick some beers despite them not having what I was looking for.

From what I've had in the past and my friend from worked confirmed it, the porter can be inconsistence. We happened to get a really good batch of porters this round, so I was pleased. 

They didn't have the DD on tap, which killed me because I love IPAs and Speakeasy's Double Daddy  is really really good. I opted for the Big Daddy and was pleased, but still really bummed.

The Tallulah Blond was good... nothing too striking, but then again I am a fan of ales, porters, IPAs, so something light doesn't really make my toes curl.

The beer at Speakeasy is good, but not the best I've had (huge fan of Stone and RR).  I still would give this place 4 stars but since they didn't have the Double Daddy, I docked it.
author: Marc T.

description: Awesome place with amazing beer. Big for me to say because I'm not a beer drinker myself, but this is a good stuff! My boyfriend and I had such a good time here, the beer tenders and the patrons add to the overall awesome experience.  We will be back for sure!
author: Daina S.

description: Nice, intimate tap room with a larger garage-like back area where they store their beer. Huge selection of their beers on tap!
author: Will D.

description:
I was here in 2007 for the first time and since then, I've had couple more pints at this place that always always always ended up with lots of fun with my friends - meaning, we just got, let's say, socially tired :)

They have Open House every Friday from 4pm-8pm, I believe.

I got only three things to say about this place:
- GREAT BEER, that for some reason tastes way better than at any other bar I've ever had Speakeasy - this beer just kicks in right away..
- $10 for 3pints?? which also means $10 to get buzzed!! what??
- never-ending nonsense talk with my friends about everything and nothing at the same time..

This place has its own special vibe and something else that I can't really describe - it's all about great beer-friends-and something else!!

PS: I highly recommend not to play piano after your fifth :)
author: Keli K.

description: Booked the free tour. Tyler is a funny and informative tour guide. Getting there wasn't too bad. Although your driving through the ghetto, then end up in an industrial area. Easy to get to. Tried the samplers of their brews....Man do they got flavor!!! Strong Porter tasted like it was described Drk. Chocolate & espresso. $1.50 for each samplers. It was pretty crowded, but it seemed like everyone stayed a bit, drank then headed out, other ppl came in to take there place. BUSY! The bartenders managed the crowd. Lots of places to sit is always a plus!! Great Experience!
author: john C.

description:
Nice place to pre-game prior to hitting downtown or something. Cheap beers ($3 a pint) and some free-tours done sporadically throughout the evening. 

They had some mexican food, mini-burritos and taquitos. Not sure if more food would've appeared as the evening wore down. 

But nice big space to chill. A group of people brought their own food/snacks and just ate.
author: Ray J.

description: So much fun, had spent many a friday after work down the way gettin our weekends started right.  Good people and potent beer.  I really like the mix of folks too as it brought all walks of life in SF (students, professionals, families, dogs)  and it works!  Solid mexican food from the local taqueria off 3rd and sometimes live music.  A great place to unwind and let loose on Friday afternoons
author: Clark G.

description: I mean...what more can be said of Katie and the crew at Speakeasy?! We were more than delightfully surprised by the atmosphere and beer here and can't wait to come back for more. If you're an IPA fan, try as many as you can...flights are easy to come by and the growlers are easy to love.
author: Katie M.

description: What A Great Place To Enjoy Some Great Beer. Service Was Awesome, Every Beer Was Explained To Us, and It Was Some Of The Best Beer I've Had. A Must Visit For Hop-Heads.
author: Walt S.

description: Speakeasy is the best beer in the bay!  Clay served us on a Wednesday afternoon. Super friendly guy, wonderful atmosphere, AMAZING prices.  $3 happy hour pints! I highly recommend this place to any micro enthusiast.
author: Keenan S.

description:
This is hard, the beer is great but its a manufacturing facility in the Bayview, its a cool place to see where they make GREAT beer but its a factory so lets get off this and rate what is real like places they serve more than just Prohibition on tap.

Please keep inviting me to the anniv parties please
author: G R.

description: I liked about 2/9 beers on their sampler. The rest just weren't my taste on that particular day. Sometimes you just have a craving for something particular. I'd say go, it's definitely worth the trek out there and they're all good beers. Pretty complex, tasty, potent, what more could you want? The place is really cozy and dark, I love it.
author: Benjamin C.

description: Hidden gem way out in Bayview. Easily accessible by muni 19 line from Russian Hill. Lots of space. Cheap drinks. Good snacks. Good times!
author: Jeanne C.

description:
ok - it all fits into place if you understand this is a brewery in an industrial warehouse, in an industrial park, in the BVHP.  No charm..nada.  It isn't the Route 29 of the craft beer world.

Beers generally very good.  Crowd a bit iffy, split between "ooh we're white people in the Bayview - aren't we rad..!", and local stoners.

And me.  Ahem.  I work two blocks away so it's my local, oh joy.

Opens Friday at 4pm.  Three bucks a serving (bit less than a pint).

Check it out!  The brewery tour is pretty bleh (guide is killing a year before heading off to grad school and is way smarter than you'll ever be..) but your call.
author: David P.

description:
I can see this place being a great place for fans of craft brewery. The White Lightning was pretty good. 

The only thing I did not understand about the tasting was that there were quite a number of small children running around--that's just strange to me for an environment like this.
author: Alyssa A.

description: Hands down one of the greatest tap rooms I have ever been to. Great atmosphere...(I was greeted by a cat when I walked in). Classic music, friendly relaxed environment. My bartender Clay knew the beer better than the brewer himself, real personable guy. Go here!
author: John M.

description:
