Firkin Fridays at Speakeasy are such a fantastic experience. Show up, pay $10 for two beers and a take home pint glass. You also have the option of plastic cups (which are $3/beer). The space is packed with equipment so don't look for any fancy seating... or really any seating. 

What you will get is an incredibly knowledgeable staff, a tour of their set up, and pretty great beer. This coming from someone who isn't a huge beer drinker, either.
author: Half P.

description: A brewery turned into a bar on Friday nights. A very cool concept. Very cheap, tasty beer. It's always a sight coming here as this is the only place you will see mothers bringing their five year old children. popcorn is free to nibble as you get drunk with good company. a good place to come to unsettle the long work week and to start the weekend right
author: Matthew G.

description: I came here for the 1st time for SF Beer Week and I am wondering what took me so long to make it here.  Friday from 4-8pm is when the brewery is opened to the public. Tours of the facility and beer making process are offered. I was loving the $3.00 a pint cost.  There is a private lot but there is also ample street parking. There is a stage for some musical entertainment. There are a few snacks also. I will be back on a warm Summer Friday... I can't wait.  Cheers for Beers!!
author: Infodiva B.

description:
If you're looking for Fantastic Friday Fun, you've come to the right spot. Totally 5 stars for beer week, and even above average 4 for a normal Friday. The warehouse atmosphere is pretty bomb.

I actually wasn't a huge Speakeasy fan before visiting the brewery. For some reason, the regulars, while tasty, fall somewhat short of my relatively high beer expectations. I'd take a Dogfishead 90 minute or Racer 5 any day over the Big Daddy.

Buuut their specialty beers rock. What's better than one daddy? Clearly,  triple the daddies (okay I think technically it's called The Don, but I prefer triple daddy).  And the Old Godfather Barley wine is pretty rad. 

I pretty much try to steer clear of any beers under 10% when I go. 

Usually some form of live music, ranging from acceptable to awesome. The same goes for quick bite options.
author: Monica C.

description: If you like good beer, you can't beat happy hour here from 4pm -9pm on Fri and Sat.  I sampled their Prohibition Ale and it was very tasty--a nice roasty, toast brew with a clean finish.  All pours are $3 a pint.  Beer doesn't get much fresher since they brew it on site.  You can buy bottles to go or get a growler. I liked the warehouse atmosphere too.
author: Shane C.

description: Oh, how I love thee and all your glory. Great spot and so glad it's close to our house. Keep on keeping on.
author: F.f. Durst D.

description: Huge fan of this local brewery even more so now with the tap rooms . Had a wonderful time celebrating my graduation here (all planned by my lovely girlfriend). Friendly and knowledgeable staff and an ever growing list of brews.
author: Wei W.

description: I was drawn out by some friends to experience the warehouse in early 2012 on a rainy Friday night when beers used to be $3 per beer token. What a blast! Still love this place today. I feel like I come for the awesome smell of all the brews-a-brewin' when really, the beer is delicious!  I just wish I could find their same selections in my local markets. Today I enjoy the new lounge and informative friendly staff!  Always a great time.
author: Samantha Ray M.

description:
Came here on a Friday around 430 pm. Easy to find, cheap beer right from the source. Pretty casual, my boyfriend and I were dressed up, we felt a little out of place, but we were going to a nice bar in SF later. 

We bought a case for about 40 bucks. Not a bad deal for good beer. And a little poster for our kitchen. Can't wait to come back again.
author: Jen M.

description: This place reminded me of microbreweries in Texas, with its laid-back vibe and seemingly middle-of-nowhere location. While it's a bit too far to be a regular destination, I'll definitely be back for any special events. They have a great selection of brews and the taproom is a comfy place to enjoy a few.
author: Brett B.

description: It's a very nice and clean taproom. bartender was nice and atmosphere was great, I will be back!
author: Mary S.

description:
Cheap and tasty beer in the Bay view.  However, this is not a bar.  It is more like a warehouse filled with kegs wrapped in plastic bagg and a giant tank of beer sitting outside in the back.  They have a decent selection of beers for only $3/ full cup (or you can pay $10 for 2 beers and a glass pint to take home).  This pretty much summarize a good place to come hangout after work.  You get drinks at a happy hour price without having to show up early during the weekday.

Besides beers, they also have some snacks such as tamales, burritos, and enchiladas for sale....not to mention free popcorn.

Since this place is located in a not-so-hip area of the city and kind of way out there, parking is never going to be a problem even on a Friday evening/night.  In case you have way too much to drink to drive home safely, you can potentially leave your car here overnight and come back to get it on the next day with the car being intact and untouched.
author: Numrin T.

description: My friends came from San Diego and wanted to check it out. Although we were touring the other side of the city, we made the long journey, and it was absolutely worth it. Even though there were fewer drafts available than usual after SF Beer week, there was still an impressive selection. Most of our group went with the Double Daddy (delicious), but one of my friends had the Belgian White IPA, which I also thought was  really good. There's no food here, but they make up for it with an intimate and interesting atmosphere. The speakeasy theme and decorations kept it cozy, split rooms kept the experience private (but there is a public area and bar if that's what you prefer), and board games kept us having a great time. Shout out to the giant Jenga game that we played to the ceiling in one game. The best part by far though was the hospitality shown to us by Ronnie (security) and John (the bartender). They made this a truly unforgettable experience. We will be back and this is a need "must see" on our list for visitors.
author: Elizabeth Z.

description: This is a San Francisco gem. World class fresh beer, cool folks, and snacks from La Laguna Taqeria. When the weather is nice, as it often is in this side of town, you can freely hang in the outdoor entry area and chat as you sip the liquid gold they serve for $3 per cup. Easily accessible by cab or public transit on the T Third line if you don't feel like driving. Seems like all walks of life congregate here, from Noe Valley baby-stroller pushers, to blue collar types from the many warehouses in the area, to Dogpatch hipsters. Everyone can freely enjoy themselves in this comfortable spot to taste serious quality. We highly recommended this place for happy hour!!!
author: Jones E.

description: $3 for a beer on practically any evening, including a weekend. You can't beat that- I don't care what you say. It's pretty cool. The space is pretty basic and feels a lot like a standard warehouse, but you can stand around a barrel with some friends and enjoy this spot before heading around to other bars in the city.
author: Nathan O.

description:
place is pretty cool.

the night i went there was the friday before st pattys.

greeted by chill bouncers.

$3 a chip...1 chip for 1 beer.

that night i hadnt eaten any dinner and for some reason ended up getting 8 double daddys, and 3 other ones.

i most likely was "that guy" that was drunk.

luckily my homie was randomly there and i guess i left with him.

better that then walking from hunters point to downtown!!!

i dont see myself coming here every friday.

however i do intend on making many random visits.

oooh cant forget the cheap snacks and good tunes.
author: Brian W.

description:
Strong Beer, Laid Back, Free Popcorn! This is the way to enjoy life. 

This place feels like a gem among the sketchy neighborhood.  We didn't feel scared walking from our car to the warehouse since we seemed to be in an office/industrial area with nobody on the streets.

Parking was easy.

Bring Cash - the card machine was broken the night we went and we had to venture out in bayview to get to an ATM. Also - you might want to eat a taquito or burrito from the table that had them for sale. 

Huge plus - it wasn't that crowded. I highly distaste bars and drinking establishments that I feel like a canned sardine or where I feel pressured to hurry up so somebody else can sit down and drink right after me. 

Standing room only - with a few random tables - but mostly for the folks who brought their young toddler kids! 

Strong Beer - eat something before you go if you're going to enjoy it. Especially if you're a light weight like me.  Two beers, no food for 6 hours, equals very tipsy evening and me falling asleep on the car right home. . Yeah for my husband restraining and being the DD! Thanks honey.
author: Tina P.

description:
Went brew tasting with my son, Andrew, while visiting the bay area. Speakeasy Ales and Lagers, a brewery,  opened at 4 PM and when we arrived there were a lot of people waiting to taste brew. Turns out they were have a Halloween Party (Friday preceeding Ghoul Day).  Pints are $3 and they were offering 2pints plus a logo'd pint glass for $10. 

Really enjoyed the Double Daddy and the Satchmo Stout.  Great people, great beer. Very enjoyable time.
author: Jay K.

description: Live music, $3 beers, and in the middle of a brewery and their equipment. It is in the outskirts of Hunters Point, but not near any of the scariness. Honestly, I have no other words for this place other than: THREE DOLLAR BEERS! Why would you rate them anything less?!
author: Anita W.

description:
I am a believer, a kool-aid drinker - whatever you want to call it, I just love this place. I came in for the first time not really knowing what to expect and left one truly happy camper. Here is what you should do:

1. Walk in when they open at 4pm sharp and get an awesome pint glass (to take home) and 2 beers for $10 (yes, that's right). 

2. Make sure you've got plenty of time to grab a pint and then get in on the 4pm tour where you can learn how they make all of their oh-so-wonderful beers. And they know what they're talking about, my chemist friend and I (a bioengineer) agreed.

3. Time the tour to finish your pint and grab another. I suggest the Hunter's Point Porter (totally amazing but be sure to try the different porters they have aged, for example in a Zinfindel barrel).

4. Wander the eclectic crowd...have some interesting conversations. 

5. Repeat steps 3 and 4 until you get kicked out at 8pm. Additional beers are only $3 (no, that is not a typo).

Also, be prepared that their beers have a pretty high alcohol content. from about 6-7% to the 13.8% Godfather. Pace yourself, and savor each sip of the wonderful tasty beer.
author: Amber P.

description:
Their beer is good. If you go there to visit, don't expect some kind of fancy tap room or restaurant. You'll be getting your beer right from a keg hooked to a tap, you'll literally be in their warehouse next to pallets of beer, kegs and the actual vats. In that way it's cool - you can show up on a Friday and get to drink all the beer you want for $3 a pint (or 2 for $10 plus a free pint glass). 

I liked their probation and brown sugga beers, and my girlfriend loved their IPA and Double IPA (big daddy and double daddy). They only have about 10 or so beers at any time, since it's a smaller place, but they really cover the different kinds of beer and the different flavors. Most breweries I go to have a lot of the same type of beer, and focus on doing what they do. If you don't like that kind of beer, you won't like the brand. But Speak Easy doesn't do that - from their IPA's to their Wheat to the Brown Sugga, they run the beer gambit and do a pretty good job at it.

If you have never been and are a beer purest, I think you would enjoy checking out their brewery on Friday nights. I'm not a huge beer freak, but I enjoyed myself and the few pints of beer I got to enjoy - and the best part is I got a few hours of fun for less then $20!
author: Erik B.

description:
I have to say, I had one of the radder dreams in my life after getting midday tanked on the Barley Wine some time ago. There was this dragon, see... and I was running along it's back as it sped along through the sky. As I ran, I had to dodge the spines which protruded from its stony skin and when it finally turned, hovering with such might that the sky seemed to shake, it stared at where I stood and steadily began to reach for me.

I woke up drenched in sweat with the meanest case of painful stand-up wood. It was pretty amazing.
author: Roy M.

description:
I can't believe I live soo close to this place and JUST found out about it recently. Be warned that they brew some serious beer here and its not for the faint of heart. A good tip is to eat before you come because the Big Daddy IPA and the Double Daddy will get you drunk! 

It's a cool place to go with a group of friends, a very relaxed environment, there isn't anywhere for you to sit so you just have to stand around and mingle! A unique thing about this place you have to purchase poker chips when you first walk in and trade off the poker chips for beer, 1 chip is 3 dollars and its good for one beer. I will definitely be back for more =)
author: Karena P.

description: Truthfully not the biggest beer drinker, but I am definitely working on it.  This was a great place to encourage my pursuit in liking beer.  My girlfriend and I decided to do the Yelp field trip event here and had a great time.  Though it was a little packed and chaotic at first it also seem to run together smoothly enough.  We got to try flights of beer (I fancied the wheat one the most)  and got a nice personal tour of the place.  The people working there definitely are knowledgeable and seem to share a genuine love for the product they create.
author: Rebecca D.

description: Excellent beer. Place was really cool initially, but lately the times I've gone it seems to have gotten way trendier and snootier plus the stench of BO is rather off-putting. Would prefer to drink their delicious beer at a bar that has a better atmosphere.
author: Jasmine B.

description:
You have to love a brewery that opens up its warehouse on Friday nights to families and friends. For 10 bucks you get a pint glass and two tastes. You can buy some tamales from a local vendor if you get hungry but I prefer the free popcorn. 

I love a place that welcomes the community like this and everyone that works there is very friendly. Bring some cash for some swag - they have a good selection. After a couple of beer, a shirt printed with "Who's Your Daddy?" just makes sense...
author: Layla M.

description:
Another great bay area brewer doing what they do best -- brewing beer. The location is a bit out of the way and not that appealing from the outside, but once you get inside it's a great way to spend a Friday afternoon happy hour.

We got a private tour from Kush, who spent about an hour walking us around the operation -- we're total beer dorks so plenty of questions. Meanwhile, the Big Daddy fresh from the tap tasted perfect.

The crowd is a random mix of people, so anyone can feel right at home. It's certainly not a classy endeavor -- the only chairs looked like castoffs from my 3rd grade library and the music was a random hodgepodge of classic rock from someones iPod. Most importantly however is the beer -- and Speakeasy makes some FANTASTIC beer. Get some.
author: Andy S.

description:
This place was the third and final stop on my tour of SF breweries. Looks like a cool place to stop by on Fridays after work. They serve beers right inside the warehouse/production area and give really short but informative tours as well. I think they're only open to the public on Fridays from 4-9. 

If you like to eat something with your beer...I suggest you bring your own food. When we were there, they had a popcorn machine. Good enough for me. I wouldn't recommend drinking their beers on an empty stomach...because as others have said...these beers will knock you on your ass!

Paid 10bucks to get a souvenir pint glass and 2 tokens for 2 pours. Got the Double Daddy IPA which was very good and STRONG. I believe it's either 8 or 9% alc. Second beer was the White Lightning. Tasty.

Glad I wasn't driving because I basically passed out in the car on my way back to our hotel!
author: Matthew S.

description: It's pretty fun to go have some drinks in a brewery.  It's also pretty fun to have some beer creation with a very high alcohol content that leaves you giddy.  We went for the deal where you get two tokens and a glass for $10 or some amount like that.  Some of the beers I really didn't love but after I got a buzz on it mattered less how bitter they tasted.  We also went back for a few more tokens.  We didn't get to really take a brewery tour because they were done before we got there but we peeked around anyway.  This is a fun alternative to a bar, especially if you are showing around a tourist *ahem*.
author: Jess K.

description: was here for a friend's bday... awesome place they have lots of games including Giant Jenga
author: Astha S.

description: Beers are good but I was here for the SF Fun cheap event.  What a fucking shit show.  Lines galore.  There is a line for getting in.  A line for getting tokens.  A line to get beer.  A line to scratch my fatty balls.  A line to find a space in the corner.   I was in line for 2 hours.  If I was smart like some tards that went to this thing I should have just cut in front of the beer line.  The event was very disorganized and straight up a shit show.  I would maybe go back on a normal day.
author: Fatty A.

description:
When we became parents, Friday afternoon happy hour became a problem. Speakeasy solves the problem perfectly. Leave work a little early, grab the kiddie and Mrs., and head down to Evans Ave. There's plenty of kids and parents, as well as plenty of everyone else. 

And it goes without saying, the beer is terrific. As I write this I'm enjoying a growler of their India Black Ale, which I got at their Firkin Friday yesterday. It's probably one of my favorite beers of all time, and only available at the brewery.
author: Neil S.

description:
I promise you one of the happiest happy hours you will ever have!!!

This place is awesome!

Every Friday they open their doors for the weekly brewery tour + happy hour. 
The tour is optional, so if you want you can just go to drink. But you can also drink on the tour of course.
Every Speakeasy beer from tap for a very reasonable price. But be aware, if you try 'em all you're head may hurt the next morning. 

I recommend: Grab all your friends and bring 'em to the Speakeasy brewery at 4pm on Friday! Every Friday!
author: Alex M.

description: What else could you expect from the makers of Big Daddy. Came on a Sunday, almost the whole place to myself! Cheap tasters @ 1.50 each.
author: Brandon S.

description: Came here for Butchertown Hoedown, rather late but there was still plenty of food, beer, and people around. Having been drinking their beer since I converted from Coronas, it was nice to check out the actual brewery. Food trucks and live music were great, the lines for beer were never too long but... the line and state of portapotties at the end of the night - eeks!
author: Tatyana K.

description: $3 quality beers. Love their IPA's. Very fun place to go and drink a few. Bring friends!
author: Mark K.

description: This place is nuts! It's a little far out of the way (I live downtown), but it was a lot of fun. Beers are super cheap and the atmosphere is very fun. It's literally located in the brewery and you're drinking $3 beer amidst cases and cases of it.  The security was very nice, although some of the clientele were less than desired (belligerent drunks...)
author: Lauren F.

description: Great BEER! Crowd was a little dead but the beer was great. Disappointed they don't sell growlers but I will be back.
author: Jesse M.

description:
You must be strong to drink this beer. Otherwise it will kick your ass....


...but it will do so in a lovely warehouse with great happy hour prices and a tour to boot. Only on Fridays though so stop being such a pansy ass and practice your drinking in anticipation early in the week.
author: Drue C.

description:
How fun is it to drive out to Hunters Point and get loaded?

Lots!

I do believe this is the only spot on earth that puts Double Daddy (the 9.5 percent APV shit-kicker) on draft and lets you double-fist said shit-kicker as you stumble around a working brewery, banging your fist on giant tuns, sticking your nose into jars of hops and asking all sorts of dumb questions. It's beer. It's good. Shut up and drink it.

Of course, it does create a 7:45 p.m. conundrum, when they kick your shitfaced ass out onto Evans Ave. But that's your problem, not theirs.
author: Chris R.

description:
I don't give too many 5 star reviews, but Speakeasy deserves its high rating.

The first time I went here with friends on a foggy Autumn Friday night, we overshot where to turn (look for Keith Street and a pair of cartoon eyes on the side of a warehouse building), and kept driving on Evans... further into Hunter's Point.  I think we past a sign that actually said "Welcome to Hunter's Point." The 'i' might have been dotted with a bullet hole.  And the further in we went, the more it looked like we were heading into Silent Hill or an abandoned Raccoon City.  Just make sure you know where this place is.

You purchase chips at the front, uh, desk that can be exchanged for the the beer inside.  $3/chip.  And the popcorn is free, so don't be afraid of grabbing some for yourself and friends.  There's other food options there, but I never tried any as I'm there for the beer.

As for the beers, they are nothing short of delicious and strong.  I'm usually a chatterbox, and I definitely was while I was there drinking there.  But 3 beers later (1st. Big Daddy, 2nd. White Lightning, and 3rd. Double Daddy)... and I was pretty much out for the night and ready to crash.  Even my friends were asking me why I was so unusually quiet.  Any beer that can make me shut up in awe = magic elixer.
author: Mercutio k.

description:
Great beer, laid back atmosphere, set in the warehouse, with friendly staff , easy parking - what else could we ask? I tried their barrel aged porter for the first time and it was quite good. Unfortunately, I got there too late for the brewery tour. Oh well, maybe next time when I can sneak out of the office early enough.... 

Fridays only and you do have to drive through no so happy neighborhood, but it is definitely worth the visit.

By the way, you can actually have Speakeasy beer in Tokyo (at Bulldog Pub in Ginza)!!!    Only in bottles, but still pretty amazing that somebody is distributing their beer in Japan..
author: Yuko K.

description:
If beer is love then I've found my wet, belch-inducing soulmate and its name is Prohibition Ale. 
Came down on a beautiful Friday afternoon, hoping the crowd wasn't full of Mission dicks or monied douches.  Instead found what I now think of as "my people": hip, casual and beer-lovin'
Love the chill warehouse vibe, the $1 snacks and the incredibly fresh beer.  But please bring back the Speakeasy growlers!
author: shane o.

description:
Where else in this city can you get a pint of 10.5% beer for $3?  And then take that beer with you on a free brewery tour?  

Ok, Ok so maybe Anchor brewery gives out samples of their beers on their tour, but good luck getting a Friday reservation there.  

The catch (of course) is that Speakeasy is only open on Fridays from 4-8pm.  The tour starts around 4:15, but don't worry if you miss it, you'll still be able to enjoy all the $3 pints and free popcorn you want.
author: dan d.

description:
Dear Speakeasy,

In the past year i have paid for your salaries, your advertising and half of your R&D dept. 

I have even helped to fund your "Secret Anti Ninja Device" that is located "In an undisclosed location."

And when you needed the help of myself and the Global Diabolical Shitstorm Inc, to fend off dinosaurs that had been genetically engineered to turn beer into the urine of a lhasa apso, i was there.

And i have to admit, YOU were there when i drank alot of you and i looked in a mirror and said "No....not tonight, youre way too fat for that dress." 

And your Big Daddy IPA was there for me the night i was playing Gran Turismo 4, and too many of you enabled me to simulate shitfacingly driving an 800hp Nissan Skyline through the streets of Tokyo at 226 mph.

And finally, when no one said that time travel was possible, i drank 12 Double Daddies and in an instant, i was at my prom, crying about a rumor that my date was "manually administrating" a tweaker in a 1987 Dodge Caravan.

As i smash this empty bottle of Stella on the ground (well yeah, i drank the whole thing (well, 3..ok?...its still BEER) i curse the fact that nothing tastes as amazing as your IPA's.

I salute you Speakeasy, for always being by my sides, and in my insides.

Love, Your friend Mick.
author: Mick F.

description:
Seriously, why the hell are you in bayview??

Oh yeah...to go to speakeasy. It is pretty impossible to spot. Look for giant eyeballs on the side of a building. I swear, you really aren't making those up, no matter how much weed you've had. All the same, you'll pass it like 15 times if you aren't paying attention, so *pay attention* drunky.

The best part *ever* about this place?? $3 *good* beers. Wow. That totally makes it a superb happy hour place. The lamer parts are the lack of tables, and the total kick your ass out the door policy at a incredibly early 8PM...yeouch. Free popcorn, and cheap mediocre mexican food is available too when you realize that you really should have dropped some ballast before doing a ton of 7% beers. Bring out of towners here, they will be blown away that you know of some really sweet out of the way place, and you might even get laid.

No liquor (duh, its a brewery), but for this liquor guy, I've always left tanked enough for the beginning of a wild night out (just like I am right now...). Time to do some coug hunting...where the hell is my safari hat and whip?
author: Sean C.

description:
"One of these things is not like the other"

That's what me and the bf (Filipino girl/white guy) looked like in this Hunters Point/Bayview area.

But deep within this neighborhood, lies the Speakeasy brewery, which is only open to the public from 4-8 pm on Fridays.  We were scheduled to take a tour of the brewery, but missed it due to personal reasons.  
But we did get to enjoy a beer there. The beers are STRONG! (double daddy- about 9% alc.) and for $3/pint, what an awesome way to have a gangster party. 

And if you have the munchies they have a mini popcorn machine that you can get popcorn from.
author: Valerie P.

description:
Happy Hour in Heaven. Go to Speakeasy

While a packed bar with no happy hour specials full of your colleagues and other FiDi folks along the water front might sound dreamy. Mine is a giant warehouse. Stacks of kegs and cases of beer provide the decor and seating. Rocking music, a good BBQ or tacos. And excellent prices on the best beer in the area. You know what? Stay at your bar.
author: Ryan G.

description:
If you're looking for an excuse to visit the Bayview, this is it.  No doubt the employees here were looking for an excuse to stop working early on Friday, and so they open up the brewery (which is basically just a warehouse with some beer vats and lots of beer cases) to the public from 4-8.  Yes, you can walk around on your own and check out the bags of mystery ingredients (diatomaceous earth?) and the whiteboard keeping track of how much beer they made this week (now that's the job for me).

At the bar they had the usual beers for $2.50 a pint, plus the "Street Sweeper", a brewery-only, 10.5% ABV wheat beer that's really more of a barley wine.  As I was the DD, unfortunately I had to stop drinking after just one of those babies.  You can also just pick up any of the cases of beer laying around and buy it.  Oh, and there's also free popcorn, chips & salsa.  When the salsa bowl ran dry, we had the following exchange:

Me: "Hey, you guys got any more salsa?"
Bartender: "Yeah, there's a big jar of it in the fridge in the office over there."

So, I get to go into the office and fetch the salsa.  That pretty much sums up the DIY experience here.  Someday, when Speakeasy becomes a big, slick operation, with reservation-only tours that are a major tourist attraction in the trendy neighborhood of NoHuPo, remind me to bitch about how it used to be.
author: Wes M.

description:
Holy cow! Mapquest's directions almost made me shit in my pants! It told me to go past the brewery and around the neighborhood down the block. So, just a warning for dummies like me, make a right onto Keith St from Evans Ave! 
I really enjoyed being scared shitless then coming to calm down my nerves with fresh beer. I tried the White Lightning and Big Daddy. Both were good and the Big Daddy one was strong and weed tasting like. The Double Daddy one intimidates me but I'm planning to try it on my next visit along with the Prohibition Ale. Anyhow, this place is a pretty kickback place. There's some seating, but minimal. Everyone just stands around barrels chatting it up. There's also little kids running around. Quite interesting I must say.
FYI, minimum for credit cards is $20 or something along those lines.
author: Lee N.

description: Good beer, friendly people, cool space, chill vibe = 5 stars
author: Bumble B.

description:
Tips for a successful date at the Speakeasy Brewery:

1. Do not show up to this place expecting an actual eating/drinking establishment. This is a warehouse. With beer. With people who make beer. WIth people who enjoy drinking beer. With people who enjoy standing in warehouses drinking beer. Dress accordingly.

2. Brush up on your washer playing skills. Hint to the uninformed: Much like the game of horseshoes, but with washers. Rules can be amazingly complicated for such a basic game.

3. Brush up on your aim with said washers, as when thrown while drinking $2.50 microbrews, the pitch can be a bit wild and dangerous.

4. Dogs like to chase washers because they are playful and excited about running around in a warehouse. Bring some sort of treat for the dogs to entice them to return the washers so you don't look like a complete ass in front of your date when chasing these playful suckers around the warehouse to retrieve your washer.

5. Enlist the aid of a designated driver. When delicous beer is $2.50 and there are happy people, dates and dogs you can get carried away.

6. Bring some type of food. Popcorn provided, but really, how impressed would your date be if you randomly pulled out some spectacular cupcakes that you baked specifically for the beer drinking occassion. Nothing says "let's get it on later" like beer and cupcakes, am I right?
author: Elissa D.

description:
Visited the Brewery thank to an sponsored Yelp Field trip. The trip included a free beer sample plus a guided tour of the brewery. The tour of the small brewery was well conducted and the guide very knowledgeable of the brewing process. As other reviewers have pointed out, they sell no food inside except that yesterday they had the Fogcutter food truck and a sandwich stand at the entrance. It was a mixed crowd considering the fact that it was a by invitation only event. Lots of hipster types which looked to me like Yelp employees. The beer is bought by tokens only and you have to do a line to buy them. They also sell six packs and growlers. Big Daddy without doubt, is their flagship beer and I would have love to buy a growler but yesterday they were not filling the growlers so I did not buy one. 
Thanks to Yelp for the invitation but the drive from the Outer Richmond to the Bayview  is a complicated one and I can get their beers at my local market.
author: Frank B.

description: Found this place via Yelp! Amazing place. Microbrewery that opens thier warehouse on Friday nights to the public. Full on neighborhood vibe. Amazing IPAs. Stood out cause I was by myself and not dressed in black from head to toe. Ghetto neighborhood place my arse! Crowd was ok, but not the most welcoming.
author: Sig K.

description: Fridays at Speakeasy should be a ritual in any young beer-lovers life.  Warning: come for the beer, not the environment.  This place is just a big open space with little seating.  Conveniently located close to UCSF if you want to pre-party before/after beer hour.  The Big Daddy is one of my favorite malty-IPAs.
author: Matt G.

description: Smaller Speakeasy brewery.  3 dollars a beer or 10 bucks for 2 pints and keep the glass.  Located in the heart of the ghettos of SF.  Worth coming once but that's about it.
author: Allen T.

description:
I was kidnapped yesterday at 3:42PM by Erin R. and Brooke G. who had apparently come looking for me at 10:31PM the previous day. Unfortunately for them, they did not write down the directions or address for their planned destination and we drove around aimlessly in Hunter's Point (aghhhh!!! it wasn't even on the tourists map we had in the car!) This however worked out perfectly because we arrived just in time for Speakeasy's happy hour. $10 for 3 pints of beer and a Speakeasy pint glass! Sweet. The beer was excellent. Between 4 girls I managed to try them all and I really can't decide what was my favorite although the Double Daddy did knock me on my ass. Double the hops and double the alcohol content. Note: I still have my 3rd token. 

My outing at the Speakeasy turned out to be a huge success. We met some guys there that arrived in the most ridiculous contraption I have ever seen in my life. (Pictures will be posted as soon as I locate my camera.) Erin R. described it as a surrey. But think of it as a 4 person bicycle with a central steering wheel and cup holders. We rode this thing down Evans and somehow managed to not get hit by a bus, involved in a drive-by shooting, or pulled over for a DUI. WHew.  I think I was screaming the entire way but it was quite a ride.
author: Lauren Y.

description: So we checked out this joint this Saturday, just the girls. Located in a warehouse.People inside and out. We walked up and it looks like a beer lovers paradise, that is if your willing to stand in line for ....along time to get tokens, first. Then gotta wait in another long line to get your beer ( Scarface was pretty good if you like real dark) But have no fear there is a band playing and lots of cool people to spark interesting conversations with. You can't help but mingle and drink which always makes for a good time. There is a food truck, but only one. Its completely laid back and chill so a good way to spend an early evening with hours from 4-9pm. I had a good time but once is enough for me.
author: shirley c.

description:
Warning - If you do not like hop-py beer, this is not the place for you.

A friend of mine was visiting from the UK.  He's a microbrew fan, and has enjoyed Magnolia's IPA for several years now.  Thankfully, Yelpers pulled through and told me about a few other possibilities in SF for us to enjoy new beers.

Arrived at Speakeasy on Friday around 6:30 pm.  Happy hour was going strong - looked like a bunch of regulars.  I didn't realize that the happy hour actually happens INSIDE the brewery!!  Great deals on beer (3 pints for $10 including glass worked well for my friend).  While I don't care for hop-py beer (even the pale ale was quite hop-py), my friend was in hops heaven!!  He loved Big Daddy and even tried the Double Daddy (9.5%) and stated it was the first beer with that percentage of alcohol that he could actually enjoy drinking.

The people who worked there were very friendly and it was a great, casual atmosphere.  We walked ourselves around the brewery and I even tinkered at the piano for a bit.

Definitely a place to visit if you're into this type of beer.  It is a bit "out there" in terms of where it's located in San Francisco.  But don't let the Hunters Point/Bayview region listing scare you.  This area is very industrial and seems quite safe!
author: Melanie N.

description:
Hey it's me the Taco Chick!
 I'm here every Friday selling Chicken and Potato taquitos.  If you guys like the food here, you should definitely come check out our restaurant La Laguna on 3rd and Fairfax.  Tell them I sent you!
Speak Easy is the perfect place to hang out and not worry about any type of drama.  Straight chill, have a good time and meet some really cool and interesting people.  I'm not a beer drinker but damn they have good beer.  White Lighting!!!
author: Ayde C.

description:
I love speakeasy beer and their events are a lot of fun.

However, I am giving them 1 star on principle because they don't belong in the top 5 night life options on yelp, seeing as how they are not open to the public 99% of nights.

They are open on Fridays from 4-8 and other infrequent special occasions. I've never had a bad Speakeasy beer, and the brewery is well worth a visit (especially at one of their anniversary parties), but it is miscategorized.

Change the categorization to reflect the fact that Speakeasy is not a place to visit for "nightlife" and I will adjust my rating accordingly.

Edit 11/27/08:

I can now give Speakeasy 5 stars with a clean conscience, knowing that they are no longer bogarting a coveted spot at the top of the SF nightlife listings! Really, Speakeasy produces some of the best beer in SF. You can't go wrong with $3 pints straight from the source!
author: Brian H.

description:
Good clean fun for the whole family.
Friday's happy hour is a such a good deal and a great chance to hang out after the work week.  There were lots of kids there too, and I appreciate places where parents can relax that also welcome kids.
Bring a coat if you are coming out during the winter months since it's basically just a brewery warehouse with a big open door.
They'll fill any growler for you too.
Yum!
author: Jessica L.

description:
Most of their lighter beer is more bitter than I tend to like it, but the black, and the maibock, and the stout!  Oh, the sweet, sweet stout.  godDAMN that shit is good.  And yet, you refuse to bottle it!  You bastards!
Oh, and they throw a mighty fine party too.
author: Don H.

description: Great beer! Pretty awesome place to come to after work on Friday for a cheap beer and some snacks.
author: Josh S.

description: Got a little sunburned sitting on the curb but it was a fine event that late Saturday in August and the pulled pork sandwich was divine!
author: Tracy A.

description:
Awesome place for amazing beer for cheap.  Wish it was open later.  Free popcorn is helpful after even one Double Daddy.

Drinks: 5/5
Ambiance: 4/5
Service: 4/5
author: M R.

description: This place is awesome. Good beer, good folks, good food. what more can you ask for. every friday from 4-9 they sell $3 pints or 2 pints and glass you get to keep for $10. and every last friday of the month, on top of all the great beers they already serve, they put out new ones they are trying or are about to release, they have other vendors there serving food, and they also have live music. Definitely one of my favorite spots to hang out or at least start your night at.
author: Mark Shane B.

description:
$5 each (thats 2+ pints) and my friends and I were all stumbling around wondering who was going to drive home. 

Speakeasy provides the awesome beer, some fun toss the ring into the hole games, tours if you call ahead of time or ask nicely, a piano, music playing over the loud speaker, some outside space either in front or out back next to the trash cans...

To improve your experience - have a designated driver, cabby, bus fair (T muni line, 19 and 44 bus will get you there)

Bring some pizza or burritos or something with you - they'll have popcorn or cookies out sometimes but bringing some food will make all the other drunkards at the joint mighty jealous.
author: Inna H.

description:
Great spot to check out at least once and probably more.  It's basically a warehouse with beers available for your consumption.  

I went with a friend last week and the night we went, it was actually a benefit party so we paid a $10 donation and they provided food with the donation.  Some Hot Links, salad, coleslaw, chips and cookies.  And of course, they always have the free popcorn that I've been hearing about.  

For the drinks, since me and friend were newbies, we went with the combo deal.  $10 for 3 beers and you get to keep the Beer Glass with the Speakeasy Logo.  I think the next 3 times I come here, I will get that deal so I can get a set of 4 glasses.  LOL...  After that, I will probably go with their regular pint price, which is $2.50 per beer.   

Since we didn't come here on a regular happy hour night, I am not sure if my next experience might be different here.  Since it was a benefit night, they actually had live music, some people were giving dancing lessons and the crowd seemed to be a little older.  Then again, since I have never been here, I'm not sure if the age demographics that night is normal for them.  

Definitely will be back and bring more friends.  One thing that was cool is that we met one of the workers there and he was able to tell us a little more about them and also some other great breweries in the Bay Area.  So we actually received a Free Education on Beers, brewmaking process, etc. etc. etc.  You could tell he loved his job.  Beer seemed to be his passion!  Very Nice!  Getting to work in a place that is your passion.  

Anyhow, the brewery started in 1997 so they had their 10 Year Anniversary recently.  In terms of these Friday Happy Hours, they've been doing it for almost 2 years.  Thanks for all the info Mike!  You helped enhance the Happy Hour experience for me and my friend.  

But what really enhanced it was that Double Daddy IPA.  Wooweeeee.....  After that, I was a goner!  I think it was a 9.5 on the Beer Richter Scale.    

So the only thing was that there wasn't really any seating or bar tables to set your drinks on.  Or very limited.  Not sure if they bring out more chairs and tables on regular nights.  But then again, this IS a warehouse so maybe it should just stay the way it is to keep the ambiance appropriate for its surroundings.

HAPPY HOUR DEETS: 
$2.50 pint
$10 combo deal = 3 pints + Keep the souvenair Speakeasy glass
author: Mark W.

description:
Why the legendary 5 stars of booyahness?

Well...

Because my poker buddies Steve Bruce and his bro Mike own the place (actually I dunno if Mike does... but Steve does for sure).

What? Not good enuff for you? Losing credibility am I?! Well you can take that credibility and shove it up your *censor*

Fine fine fine.

Good beer. Great IPA. Gets you drunk real fast. Support local breweries!!!!!!!!!!!! Down with the MAN!!!!! Now go read the other reviewers about Speakeasy Ales & Lagers, and they'll tell you everything you need to know about why this place gets the 5-star of booyahness. Nuff said.

Negatives:
It's seriously, in the middle of BFE.
author: Seiji N.

description: I made it for the tour this evening, and I'm glad I did. The employees are friendly, the vibe is positive and the beer is really good. I was very impressed with their Scarface Imperial Stout. It had just the right amount of sweetness, very smooth and creamy texture and great color, job well done fella's! I did the tour which was really cool. If anyone is interested in seeing how beer becomes beer, or is a beginning homebrewer, you should definitely do the tour. The brewmater, Kush, gave the tour, and not only was he a good guide, but he didn't mind hanging out afterwards to talk a little bit more about the company and beer making. It was a very cool thing for him to do. So to sum it up, good beer+ good people= good times. Thanks for the fun Friday Speakeasy!
author: Jason A.

description:
Speakeasy is definitely the place to be for happy hour on Friday evenings.  But, I don't think everyone knows that yet.  There was quite a few people there, but it wasn't packed.  The warehouse/brewery has a good set-up for going to hang out with friends and drink a few beers.  It has a very laid back atmosphere.  The beer was very tasty and the price for the beer was really good.  $10 for 3 beers and a glass to keep?!  Awesome!  Even if you don't want 3 beers and a glass, the prices are still good.  If you're hungry, they have yummy tacos with spicy salsa available.  Beer and tacos?  Could it get more perfect?!

I will definitely be spending more Fridays here.  Highly recommended!
author: TK B.

description: Great spot to meet up with friends after work or what have you. Prices are great and l couldn't complain about service. Just more places to sit would be cool. Parking was easy too. Have fun! Its worth it.
author: Zachery H.

description: This place was great!  We went on friday night.  The beer was awesome and chep, they had good mexican food and we got a brewery tour.  Very impressed.
author: Ryan H.

description:
First off, I have to admit, I've been a Speakeasy Mobster and shareholder since the late 1990s - so I am a little biased. As much as I love the current lineup of bottled beers: Big Daddy IPA, Prohibition Ale, Double Daddy Imperial IPA and the Untouchable Pale Ale (and the elusive Godfather Barleywine), it's the keg-only and the dearly departed brews that made this brewery tops in my book.

Keg Only:
The Bootlegger Black Lager holds up to the classic Sapporo Black and the archetype of the style: Kostritzer Schwartzbier. Malty and a little sweet, but also refreshing. There's a reason they're commonly called black pilsners.

The Shylock Maibock is also a great example of a German spring bock beer. Strong but balanced with a sweet malty character.

Even the Satchmo Stout, which should be bottled as there is a real lack of good local stouts, is a fantastic beer... nice and roasty and proof that stouts can aspire to be more than a Guinness.

However, the three best, most unique beers are ones that are unfortunately not being made any more.

White Lightning - their attempt at a berliner weisse, a sour beer that had undergone lactic fermentation. Even though it was a pain to produce and a bigger pain to clean out of the tanks and pipes, it was an amazing beer when stored and served properly (the trick was to make sure some live yeast made it into the glass like with a Belgian beer)

Common Beer - The San Francisco Common Beer was quite possibly the best beer produced on the west coast when it came to pairing with food, and it's a shame that restaurants all throughout the Bay Area didn't stock it. Maybe it was the name, or maybe the restaurant industry lacked the vision to pair a domestic beer with food the way they do now with Belgian brews. Either way, it is sorely missed.

Finally, the best of the bunch: Untouchable Lager - a perfect Maerzen beer, and possibly the best California-made lager I have ever had. This beer was fantastic, but unfortunately suffered in sales because the local market is biased towards ales.

The city is much better for having Speakeasy supplying its bars with fresh, local brew.
author: Avery G.

description:
To the makers of Speakeasy....

Damn you* for such tasty ales. Damn you for having a lovely chill happy hour on Friday (from 4p to 8p) where the pints are only $2.50. Damn you and your anniversary party where I was out for the count the second my drunken head hit the pillow at home (at about 6pm). Damn you for assuming that since I had to wait for 2 keg changes in 2 rounds I didn't have to pay for the 2nd round. Damn you for being so cordial. Damn you for believing in quality. Damn you for keeping it local. Damn you for having such cool logos. Damn you for being so farkin' convenient to the 19 line and Muni T line, which are accessible in either minutes or steps from my place. Last Friday, damn you, I was so blissfully unaware of my surroundings after I left you, all I can tell you for certain is that I went to Giants game and I ate a cheesesteak. I had to check the news for the actual score and highlights. 

And damn you for making me love you.

*-By the way, all those damn yous can be replaced with thank yous
author: Veronica G.

description:
If you have a personal chauffeur, Speakeasy is the place to be for Friday Happy Hour.  Located in Bayview- where even the cabs don't venture- you're unlikely to find transportation there and back (assuming you live in the city).  Driving is out of the question as well.  Why go to a brewery and have to worry about drinking responsibly? 
The best thing about going to Speakeasy is the absolute unstructured, laissez-faire attitude of the place.  The tour starts, eh, whenever, and lasts until, eh, whenever.  Cheap, quality beer, trademark bar games and some grub.  
Oh, and be sure to bring some dog treats.  I guarantee you'll make a new friend.
author: Christine M.

description:
I have never been more wasted off happy hour in my life . . . FIVE STARS 

The beer is great-- I loved the IPA and the Porter especially. Of course no one remembers to take their free 'Speakeasy" beer glasses home because after 4 of these suckers, you can barely remember your name.

If you take the muni T on a Friday, follow the line of confused twentysomethings toting shoulder bags and wearing corduroy pants  . . . they are definitely not locals and are making the pilgrimage all the way across bayview in pursuit of good beer. 

The only slight confusion to this otherwise beer-mecca experience, was the abundance of small children in the warehouse. Maybe we unwitting came on "pre-school Friday" (or more likely, these are friends/family of the brewery staff), but in general I prefer not to intoxicate myself whilst under the intense and watchful gaze of a 3 year-old child.  Ah well.
author: Chelsea R.

description:
San Francisco's pride.  The beer here is great!  Blows Anchor Steam outta the water.   Double Daddy is twice as strong as Big Daddy but also twice the flavor in my opinion.  

It's a warehouse that has a nice rotation of Friday events.  Mellow, easy going, and diverse mix of San Franciscans in the know are here.  Fun crowd, I hope it stays that way.  I hesitate to write a review to keep this one a secret.  Oh well, if you suck please don't come here.  Did I mention there's Free popcorn!?
author: Izzy Z.

description:
I've been literally attending "the Speakeasy" every Friday...well before Thanksgiving..the holidays require me to be out of town a lot.Great beer and great people!! My coworkers invited me to one of their open house/happy hour things about 3 months ago and once i stepped inside and had a taste of their wonderful beer I knew I'd becoming back many Fridays there after. A pint of one of their flavorful ales or lagers is a cheap $2.50. And if you dare to drink Double Daddy's all night (or day since happy is from 4-8) then prepare to spend only about $5-$10 to get wasted. 

I've never had a dull time at the Speakeasy but keep in mind, it's just a warehouse with a bunch of packaged kegs. If you're lucky you'll find an empty seat. 

Overall, Speakeasy is fantastic! 

Joe is awesome!!
author: Karen W.

description:
Yes, the white lightning is my beer of choice.  The others are really strong and they will get you drunk after 3 pints!  But hey, that's only $10!   I was pretty disappointed with the taquitos as I expected tacos.  They definitely need more food, and longer hours!!

BTW, do not be scared of the neighborhood.  It's nothing you'd expect once you're inside.
author: Jenny K.

description:
You immediately have the feeling you're crashing a party you weren't invited too.  There wasn't a ton of people, no chairs for sitting, and very mixed ages.

Normally you'd think these things wouldn't make a 5 star review.  But within the first 2 minutes of being there we felt at ease.  We ordered our cheap beer deal (Don't remember the numbers I didn't pay).  They gave us our chips to use (3 each) when ordering our beers. (I thought that was cute.)  The guys that work here are so sweet.  They answer any questions about their beer or if it's your first time there.

They have a guy in the back BBQing the most amazing burgers and free popcorn.  There was a band playing and a cute dog named Kaya running around.  We had a great experience, would definately go back.
author: Mary R.

description:
My introduction to Speakeasy:

After looking at the first apartment I was going to rent in San Francisco, I headed to Chow on Church Street and asked the bartender what local beer I should have.

"Speakeasy Prohibition Ale" he answered. "Its local and its gooood."

I followed his advice, and loved the beer. The same bartender told me to take the apartment I had just seen (around the corner from Chow) and I did that too. Come to think of it, he was the Yoda of bartenders, as both the apartment and the beer have served me well.

Fast forward almost 8 years - on hubby's convincing, we headed to a Speakeasy party on a sunny Saturday afternoon. $2 beers (including the mind-altering 10.5% beer not available in stores and a killer porter), punk surf bands, and an amalgamation of scooter enthusiasts not seen this side of Italy. 

Not only did I enter the scooter contest as 2nd in command, I was invited to join an all-female scooter club! The locals are friendly here, people....head to a party, drink lots of beer, and enjoy.

And designate a driver because the 44 doesn't seem to come that often!
author: Priya S.

description: Dope spot, reminds me of getting to the Pound back in the day. They are now doing every Friday & Saturdays at the brewery. If you like craft beer & haven't been here, you should.
author: David P.

description:
Who doesn't love drinking in a brewery? Mike & Joey serve the six Speakeasy beers  (Prohibition, Big Daddy, Double Daddy, Hunter's Point Porter, White Lightning & Untouchable) on tap every Friday from 4:00-8:00. Pints are $2.50 and taste so fresh!! 

They used to put out a food spread but recently they've started selling tamales, taquitos and the like. They also have free popcorn.

This is a brewery in a warehouse, so don't expect fancy decor and plush seating. You will however witness a small batch stainless steel brewing facility where you can talk with the brew master (Mike).

Fridays at Speakeasy draw a very diverse crowd: suits, union workers, hipsters, bums and everything in between. As a bonus everyone seems to get along.

There are smoking areas in the front and back.

This is an excellent venue to kick start your Friday evening festivities
author: Peter O.

description: Wow.  This place is awesome!  Scarface 9.5% solid.  Double daddy 8.5% solid.  Brewery in the back with food stations, solid.  Back space is good for big parties (which is what I came for).  Staff is super nice and easy on the eyes.  Parking lot with tons of easy parking on a Friday night.  Can I give this place 6 stars?
author: David M.

description:
A fantastic Friday Happy Hour.  Great beer at a reasonable price and an astonishing mix of people.  Don't go there for the food because it is not always available.  (Bring your own if you wish.)  The crowd and the beer can not be beat.  Joe, the usual bartender, is a riot.  People like him are one of the reasons that I love SF.
Don't expect anything fancy.  This is drinking great local brew with down-to-earth people in a warehouse brewery.  There are limited seats and often no music.  They used to have great bands but apparently they got lazy booking them.  They are only open Friday, 4 to 8.
author: Larry W.

description: I love that it is in the warehouse, its a totally different feel. The beers are delicious, even if I only got to try the blonde ale because I was driving. I'm definitely going to go back and would recommend it to any of my crew.
author: Morgan W.

description: Always loved Prohibition Ale and that led me to take the brewery tour.  It was cool.  Had some beer, got a glass and the tour was pretty damn good.  The brewer who led it had some cool insight and reaffirmed why mass produced beers are usually bland.  The actual warehouse was neat and it was easy to find and park.  Glad to have had to opportunity to check it out.
author: Sin F.

description: Neat, cool, wow. Free parking..that is all I need to say. It is definitely a different type of venue given are literally in the brewery but it makes an unique atmosphere.
author: Stephen K.

description:
The music was insanely loud and the line to get a beer was extremely long, and almost put me over the top of having a bad night, until I got a pint of beer and 2 taquitos in me, then it was half tolerable.  I think they were changing out kegs, so it backed the line way up, but there's no excuse for having music that loud.  Seriously, I'm not that old, 28, but I felt like my mom must have when I was in high school blasting my music and yelling "TURN THAT CRAP DOWN."  Oh no, I'm getting old aren't I?
Beers $2.50, 3 beers and you keep the glass $10, Taquitos $1
author: Sarah M.

description:
Thank you, Speakeasy, for your wonderful 9th anniversary party.  We drank $2 beers ALL day.  The beer was delicious, the day was beautiful, and the people were friendly.  Excellent!  

The bootlegger black lager is yummy and a little lower in alcohol (good for an all day event).  The Double Daddy (9.5%) kicks your butt.
author: Annie C.

description:
Its hard to believe  the last 10 years  went  by so fast..... but good  beer has kept me socially lubricated  and happy.

Cheers to Speakeasy  for  making  excellent  malt beverages  and keeping their  eyes  on me  at all times.
author: dan s.

description: How can you go wrong with fresh/great beer on tap with free popcorn? My dad took me here awhile back and i had no idea what I was getting into. I keep hearing people mention about the area, I mean dont get me wrong its not exactly the best surrounding area, but once your inside, your worries get less and less with each sip. They have my favorite beer, the double daddy! Great beer of choice to prime the pump. They offer live music from time to time and definitely a great bargain for your buck with the poker chips being your currency. There is also a little mexican food stand that looks pretty good, but I have yet to try. For a place that's tucked away and only open on the most crucial day of the week (fridays) you cant go wrong after a long work week to unwind with a couple of great beers. Highly recommend this place and definitely will be coming back.
author: Alex P.

description:
this place is in the most RANDOM area...but my friend always goes there practically every friday so i decided to give it a try...

this place is definetely a brewary...it reeked of beer as soon as i walked in and all you see are giant kegs everywhere...but i must say say the beer was pretty cheap and were not as bad as i thought it would be seeing how im not really a fan of ales...

but 2 beers later and your night is definetely a big blurr
author: Annie L.

description:
I just went to a bbq here the other day, and asked if I could find it again I would have to say no. It is far out there, but kind of like a little oasis on a back road. 
I think my favorite beer was Prohibition. There were some of the cutest kids dancing to the live music, i especially appreciated the boy dressed as Peter Pan. They were bringing the finest of interpretative dance to the world. 
Hopefully these bbq's happen regularly, as we had a blast.
author: Erin O.

description:
Jenny K., thank you for the introduction to this great place!

I was a bit disappointed with the mis-advertisement of tacos and they only had taquitos ($1) and veggie burritos ($3) only but I'll let that slide because 3 pints for $10 is a deal I'm enjoying. The pale ale "White Lighting" is the way I go down.....yea, I'm weak like that.
author: Katie K.

description:
The beer is f*ckin awesome.  Prohibition has always been one of my
favorites as well as Big Daddy. I cruised out to the brewery on a Friday and got a chance to try the Double Daddy for the first time. This beer is definitely not for amatuers.  After a couple of these and we were all much drunker than expected. The guys who work there seemed cool, one of the assistant brewers gave us a  tour and explained the brewing process. He probably was ready to go home because it was Friday around 5 but he stuck around and didn't seem tomind. There is no food if that is what you are expecting. Just a big wharehouse that has some awesome cheap beer. I will definitely be back!
author: John M.

description:
If you have a chance, definitely check this place out.  It's a funky, down-to-earth brewery, with a little "backyard" and plenty of parking.

As another reviewer mentioned, they have happy hour on Friday afternoons, and sometimes they have other events.  Bring earplugs though -- when they have live music, the "acoustics" of the brewery mean it's going to be LOUD.

Great beer, though!
author: Doublejack X.

description:
I love it!  

If you've never been there, here is map: http://www.indiabasin.org/map.htm

You can see them at the top right (off Evans Ave) before the closed PG&E power plant).

They rock!
author: Tori F.

description:
when i worked down the road from the speakeasy, this was our friday end of the week release.

$3 beers, free popcorn, mexican food from the local taqueria, all while you drink in amongst the vats in the brewery.

babies, dogs, and all walks of life hang out here, and let their hair down on fridays @ the speakeasy.
author: Sheri N.

description: I've been here a couple times and this place hasn't failed yet! The beer is great and its reasonably priced for a night out (or start of) in the city.  The crowd is usually pretty friendly and low key but there's always a good turn out. On New Years Eve they had a live band playing, but I'm not sure that they do that very often. I usually drink the prohibition or the double daddy. Double daddy is tasty but can get crazy for anyone with a low tolerance since its 9.5%. You are literally in the warehouse, so don't expect a super fancy experience. Oh and free popcorn!
author: lerman m.

description:
My buddy works at the factory, and i applaud his attempts at securing outside friendship by supplying free big daddy at their band practices while fellow cavorts that we didn't know prior to the popping of the top. 
Their product is a symphony of spices, this is true. They get docked a star for stopping said band from performing during the friday 4-8 slot, because "the easy listening lush brigade" just wasn't in the mood for some molten goof-metal hijinks. When i grab a 16 ounce of double daddy now, i get a little bitter before i drink the bitter. A few shards of disgust the way down the gullet, nothing too detrimental.
author: Christopher J.

description:
Awesome Beers. Love the Big Daddy. Love the Double Daddy. Love the new one - what's it called, 'white lightening" or something like that. Don't really love prohibition, but everyone else does, so it can have thumbs up in my book too. 

Love the happy hour, love the staff, love that they sometimes give me free beers. Love that they give me tours over and over of the brewery, because I love brewery tours.

Speakeasy is the best.
author: Jen B.

description:
Simple, unpretentious, friendly layout.  You will pay less for better beer and receive it faster than any other establishment you can think of.  Seriously.

For fans of lighter beers, try White Lightning (similar to Hoegarden).

For fans of darker beers, try Hunters Point Porter (similar to Guinness).

Shit, for $2.50 a pop, try them all.  

Next assignment: start making excuses as to why you have so many speakeasy pint glasses and poker chips laying haphazardly around your house along with one for that tattoo of "Bubba" in a heart you don't quite remember getting.
author: Pickles T.

description: Just tes..tasted "The Untouchables" ..."Un Believable".  You nailed it with this one.  Cheers.
author: Bill R.

description:
Friday Happy Hour = no frills, cheap beer, with "regular" folks in the crowd.  If that's your thing, then come on down (but don't bring your friends... we like it when it's not too busy.)

They basically set up a bar on the loading dock and people hang out and sample the wares.  For $10, you get a Speakeasy pint glass and 3 drink chips.  Want more than three drinks--they're $2.50 after that.  Not a bad deal at all (especially if your Ikea glassware collection needs sprucing).  Meanwhile, the crowd offers a bunch of mostly unpretentious folks loitering with beer in hand.  It's a good, mellow start to your Friday night.
author: David K.

description: Words cannot describe my love for this place. My favorite happy hour anywhere. Yummy beer. A nice crowd. Just close enough to Hard Knox for dinner. Life does not get much better.
author: Cameron K.

description: I can't believe I haven't reviewed this place yet, as they were for a while probably brewery I had visited the most. I've been on the tour here 2 or 3 times, and each time I learn something new about the process. I've had a great time at the Friday open-houses and was thrilled to see them trot out experimental and new brews beyond the usual (and super strong) regular releases. And I'm sad to say that I'll be missing this year's anniversary party, as that's become a SF tradition for me as well. Check it out if you get a chance, bring a DD or take the T-line.
author: alejandro p.

description: I've actually written this review a couple of times and then deleted it because I feel like I need to put in my two cents but want to be diplomatic about it. I am not a fan of their beer but In this case I don't want my opinion to influence anyone. This is an independent brewer and I like to support this kind of endeavor. I suggest you get down to one of their happy hours and try them out for yourself. You might try to limit yourself to 2/3 of the amount of beer you usually drink because this stuff is scarily strong; I honestly think they under rate the ABV.
author: Manny F.

description: Sitting in the Speakeasy warehouse sipping a fresh Double Daddy out of a plastic cup for $3 on a Friday afternoon with popcorn and friends is well worth the trek to SF"s shadiest neighborhood.  If only they had better seating and more food this would be heaven in a warehouse.
author: Eric S.

description: Lived in SF for nearly 4 years, and this was my first experience of Bayview/HuntersPoint. And hey, it was a good one!  I didn't get shot or worse. Coworkers went down for the Friday night happy hour, and I tried a few of their beers (including the Big Daddy). No souvenir glass though last night (3 beer chips for $9). I like that you're just hanging out in the middle of the warehouse/brewery.
author: Jen D.

description: finally came here for my birthday!  $3 beers at one of my fave breweries.  live music, southern sandwich serving up some sweet tea and brisket sandwiches.  a little bit of eye candy, and a lot of good times.  probably one of the best things to do on a friday afternoon.  ps, they're open saturday afternoons now, too.  i saw a flier and then felt like my day was less special. hah i'm crazy.
author: jennifer l.

description: Before you come out here, let it be known that it's out in the ozarks of 3rd Street! Any farther, I would've freaked out from being too far into Hunter's Point. You keep driving thinking that you've missed it, but once you see the "eye" on the warehouse, you've hit the jackpot. Open only on Fridays for happy hour and for the awesome price of $3 a beer, you can try all the goodness that Speakeasy has to offer in their shipping warehouse. A little unorthodox, I know, but after having gone it's a great time and one of the more interesting and cheaper happy hour deals in SF. Hungry? No problem. They serve popcorn. But if you're want something a little more solid, they serve taquitos or burritos to snack on.  I suggest knowing who's going to drive in advance. These beers are tasty hard hitters.
author: Grace V.

description: $3 beers! Speakeasy, you are the reason I look forward to Fridays!  I love the Hunter's Point Porter - last week I found out a limited edition is available that was aged in oak barrels - yummy!
author: Erin R.

description: There beers are easily available throughout most of the city...and the double daddy is simply a phenomenal double ipa...even the big daddy is pretty freaking good...good stuff
author: Francis K.

description:
disclaimer: i drink bud light.  because i like it.  

that being said...i love the small brewery concept.  i love do-it-yourself brewers that have a good enough product going that they can make a living off it.  i love local, small batch beers with quirky names.  i will support a brewery any day over mass produced, water down crap beer.  but i will still go home every night and drink bud light.  sorry.  

the only beer i really like at speakeasy is the white lightening.  the old man loves hunters point, which they used to have on tap at the broken record but have switched it for big daddy.  we have been to the brewery a couple times for parties or friday night open house and always have a great time.  

great space...great people...great beer.
author: Katie H.

description: Amazing beer.  Dirt cheap.  Laid back atmosphere (that's possibly an understatement).  I love this place.  Love love love love love.  I have leftover poker chips from this place laying around my house and its always a good reminder to go back next Friday and see whats on tap.  Special releases run out early but they have stuff you'll never find bottled, totally worth getting there early.  Just don't drive home.  $3 a pint plus very potent beer (i'm looking at you, double daddy) = you need a taxi.
author: Holly B.

description: I love this beer!!  If you like hoppy beer and strong beer then you'll love this stuff!!  The guys that run this brewery is awesome.  I was going away on a houseboat trip and needed to find some Double Daddy IPA.  I gave a ring to them and they told me where they recently stocked a store.  I went there and bought enough for the trip.  The other great thing about these guys is the Friday BBQ and live music.  Probably the best deal in town!
author: Timmy C.

description: The Speakeasy Brewery is without a doubt the best reason to go to the Bayview part of San Francisco. Their beers are only $2.50 a pint and, of course, damn tasty. Being able to walk around their warehouse is pretty interesting - I'm dying to know what was in the 'spill kit' that was hanging on one of back walls. There's also a piano out front near the office and I certainly like me some piano playing when drinking.
author: Cathy C.

description: I love this SF brewery.  They make bold authentic beers and have a laid back attitude.  If you've ever attended their Open House Friday happy hours you know what I'm talking about.  Every Friday from 4-8 they open up the doors to the brewery and kick back with anybody who'd like to come on down.  They setup a small bar, put a few speakeasy kegs on tap and sell pints of deliciousness for $2.50.  Free popcorn and dogs are both to be found on all Fridays and the brewery isn't that far out of the way especially if you're in the Mission, SOMA or Portrero Hill.
author: Ed B.

description: Love this Friday happy hour!  $10 bucks gets you 3 beers and a pimp-ass pint glass, bbq was bumpin' and there was a band playing surf rock.  What I totally have missed out on by going to typical SF bars are the bar kiddies!  There were all these little kids there with their hip 'rents, dancing around to the band and showing off... we even got therm to put our dollars in the tip jar.  I was so one of those kids!!  My dad always gave me quarters for the jukebox and I just rocked out!  I attribute all my dance moves to being a bar brat : )  Very cool crowd, dogs are allowed, and GREAT beer... no better way to end the week.
author: Tara G.

description: This place is a diamond in the rough! I love to come to come on Fridays and enjoy their great beer for a great price! You can't beat this deal and you get a glass too.  Just a great atmosphere, not pretentious at all.  However, you better have a DD because it's tough to get a cab to go out that way.  One time my friends and I had to get a ride from an employee to downtown because no cab would come pick us up.
author: Laura C.

description: There Hunter's Porter is bangin and it can't be found at too many other places outside of the brewery. The Double Daddy is fresh and on point. 3 cups of that will have you feeling real loose. There is also a taco vendor inside the brewery. The brewery is open on Friday from 5:00 PM to 8:00 PM or 9:00PM. $10 gets you 3 beers and a Speakeasy collector's glass to keep. Have fun. Oh yeah, don't trip off the neighborhhood its no biggie.
author: C G.

description:
really great beers -- many of higher alcohol content, which i love.  $3 for each beer -- what's not to like?? ambiance is fun, and becomes increasingly bougified and well-dressed as folks get off work.  transition is fun to see.

recommend biking there!
author: sean m.
Farajaqua S.

description: Place is awesome...highlight is walking here from the T and having a car pull over and ask if i know where I am going and then circle back to ensure my safety.  It is in an industrial area but i didnt feel unsafe until that moment. Anyways beer is great, love the white lightning and big daddy...and sometimes there is someone selling homemade taquitos with really good salsa for $1! Hell yeah! Great place to catch up with friends and have good beer for cheap.
author: Alana L.

description:
damn avery got in depth here. this brewery tour was a little more leisurely and much more informal than anchor. the place is much smaller than anchor and we were drinking while touring.

beers after the tour are $2 each which is a damn good price for such rarities. i just wish i had brought my own glass so i didnt have to drink out of plastic cups. you also get to taste their seasonal brews and they usually bbq on fridays i hear too.
author: Victor B.

description: This is my favorite place to drink in San Francisco, hands down.  Their beer is AMAZING.  The varieties they offer in the brewery are very diverse, and change frequently.  The price of $3/beer is heavenly in this city.  I took the tour, which was SO fun.  Lead brewer Kush led the tour himself, and imparted detailed information in a very personable manner.  Afterwards, the place started filling up, but since it's such a great huge space, it never felt crowded, especially with their outdoor area available.  I really enjoyed the vibe too; there were some really fun people there!  I will definitely be back with more friends.
author: j s.

description: The atmosphere is high ceiling warehouse.  The crowd is chill down to earth people trying to knock back a few after a long work week.  Plenty of space to park outside for free and enough room to walk around inside.  I only tried two of the beers there, the IPA and the Hunter's Point.  Both were solid.  Definitely coming back considering I live a few miles south by Candlestick.  Avoid the happy hour crowd downtown every once in awhile and hit up Speakeasy.
author: Law C.

description: The reason why I gave this brewery 5 stars, is because everyone is really friendly, and laid back crowds only come here. I can't wait for Friday's to enjoy Happy Hour at Speakeasy's. $3 beers you CAN't go wrong with that, and don't forget to bring your growler or buy one. Fill up the growler for beer at home :) Pet's used to be allowed, but are now banned (boo) Kid friendly spot, which is a plus for me (yay) Please watch out cause after  2 beers, seriously only 2 you are feeling the alcohol. Awesome!
author: Monica O.

description: The Friday night happy hour here is unbeatable. We took a group of 20 from my office, and started out with an awesome tour given by the head brewer himself. According to one of my coworkers it was "ten times as detailed" as the Anchor Steam tour. The pints are super-cheap for quality beer - you can get obliterated for less than $10. (Particularly if you're drinking Double Daddy - watch out for that one.) They had burritos and taquitos when I was there, which were decent for what you pay. Minus one star for being in such a random, out-of-the-way, close-to-sketchy-places neighborhood. It is not a great place to have to drunkenly find your way home from. (Somehow we thought we could get off the T at 24th street and walk to the Mission...oh wait, those are projects. Oops.)
author: Kristen B.

description: Quite simply, they make great beer. Speakeasy brew beef for enthusiasts nationwide, and limited-production boutique crafts for local consumption by those in the know. The brewery is run by a team of no-nonsense barley and hops specialists, Californians through and through, that clearly love doing their job and doing it well. In-house tastings on most Fridays. Call in advance for reservations.
author: Michael P.

description: Speakeasy beer is not for wimps, this is real beer, real good that is!!  On Fridays they have an Open House Barbecue from 4:00pm-8:00pm, with a live band usually playing!  The Speakeasy crew are really welcoming always willing to answer someone's (mine) stupid questions about the whole brewing process!
author: Cassie L.

description: Beer that drinks like a meal, and people you'll love drinking it with. Try the Friday Hour and be prepared to call for a ride home.
author: t h.

description: The beers are good.  The guys are cool.  They have very chill happy hours with good Speakeasy beers, a basic bbq and cool merchandise.  Speakeasy hoodies, bumper stickers & thongs, oh my!  Unfortunately the happy hour is only  a few hours on Friday nights, but it is still really good. They also have the harder to find beers on tap on those nights.  Also, you can get a case, growler, keg or pint.  I have a growing collection of Speakeasy pint glasses from these nights.  And a few Speakeasy poker chips. And the hoodie... and of course I've had plenty of the beer.
author: Heidi P.

description:
I love this place!
the vibe, atmosphere, beer, entertainment, and most importantly...friends
author: geneva d.

description: awesome.  not a lot going on here.  just beer and washers, but it's good.  real good.
author: Angie C.

description: Speakeasy. Double Daddy IPA flows through my veins. I worship the shelves it sits on. If I was homeless I would sleep outside of the warehouse and just breathe in hops all day.
author: David B.

description: Delicious beer and great crowd.  They have a very good happy hour on Fridays and when there is live music it is a unique venue.  Good cheap Mexican food to soak up the beer and free popcorn doesn't hurt.  Some people bring their kids which is....different and a little disconcerting when kids are running around people drinking.
author: Matt B.

description: The 9th Anniversary celebration was the first time visiting this brewery. It was really cool - almost like going to a friend's house for a BBQ. Tons of friendly people (I was suprised to see all the little kids running around) and good beer. I wish I had gotten the names of the bands that played.
author: a a.

description: This place is insane.  Its like walking into a college party in a brewery... piles of wheat, hops and kegs and everyone standing up drinking out of plastic cups.  I was surprised that I loved this place but great beer for 2.50 a pint in an unpretentious atmosphere... I have no complaints.
author: pauline e.

description: what can i say? the beer is fuckin awesome, the bbq's are fuckin awesome, the bands that play are always awesome and the employees are always kool and friendly even though one guy(i'll leave his name out) is always trying to pick up on my girlyfriend. it's always a good laugh when it comes time for last call and we all have her get the beers after they stopped serving.
author: Ausewaldoe J.
